Along with the Commentary of Mathara🔽I bow with supreme devotion to the eternal Lord of the Kapila Light,

original: sarvavidyāvidhātāram ādityasthaṃ sanātanam /🔽nato 'smi parayā bhaktyā kāpilaṃ jyotir īśvaram // //🔽kapilāya namas tasmai yenāvidyodadhau jagati magne /
analyzed: sarva vidyā vidhātāram āditya stham sanātanam  nataḥ smi parayā bhaktyā kāpilam jyotiḥ īśvaram  kapilāya namaḥ tasmai yena avidyā udadhau jagati magne

analyzed: namaskṛtya tu tam tasya vakṣye jñānasya kāraṇam

analyzed: duḥkha traya abhighātāt jijñāsā tad abhighātake hetau

analyzed: dṛṣṭe sā apārthā ced na ekānta atyantataḥ bhāvāt
translated: If it is said to be pointless when the means is seen, it is not so, because of the absence of absolute and complete [absence of suffering].

analyzed: asyāḥ āryāyāḥ upodghātaḥ kriyate

analyzed: iha hi bhagavān mahā ṛṣiḥ sāṃsiddhika dharma jñāna vairāgya aiśvarya sampannaḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: Here, the Blessed Lord, the Great Sage, endowed with inherent qualities, knowledge, detachment, and lordship, of the Blessed One

original: purāṇapuruṣasyāvatāro jagadanujighṛkṣayā prajāpateḥ kardamasya putraḥ svāyambhuvasya
analyzed: purāṇapuruṣasya avatāraḥ jagat anujighṛkṣayā prajāpateḥ kardamasya putraḥ svāyambhuvasya
translated: An incarnation of the ancient Purusha, out of a desire to help the world, was born as the son of the Prajapati Kardama, the son of the self-existent Manu.

original: manor duhitari devahūtyāṃ kapilo nāma babhūva /
analyzed: manoḥ duhitari devahūtyām kapilaḥ nāma babhūva
translated: In the daughter of Manu, Devayani, there was one named Kapila.

analyzed: sa tena guṇa puruṣa antara upalabdhi rūpeṇa jñānena apāra pāram didarśiṣayā hasta avalambena iva
translated: He, by that knowledge in the form of the perception of the difference between the qualities and the Purusha, as if by the support of a hand, desiring to see the shore beyond the shore,

analyzed: kāla ahi dandaśyamāna jagataḥ sudhāmaṇinā iva
translated: as if by the nectar-jewel of the world bitten by the serpent of time.

analyzed: duścikitsyasya bhava vyādheḥ apanayanāya samyak auṣadhena iva
translated: For the removal of the incurable disease of worldly existence, as if by the right medicine,

analyzed: avidyā andhakāra pradhvaṃsana pradīpena iva
translated: as if by the lamp that destroys the darkness of ignorance,

original: muktimārgavirodhimohavṛkṣavivraścanakuṭhāreṇevāmunāvabodhena sampanno 'ndhe tamasi majjaj jagad idam adrākṣīt /
analyzed: mukti mārga virodhi moha vṛkṣa vivraścana kuṭhāreṇa iva amunā avabodhena sampannaḥ ndhe tamasi majjat jagat idam adrākṣīt
translated: as if by the axe that cuts down the tree of delusion, which is opposed to the path of liberation, the world, which was drowning in blind darkness, was seen by him endowed with that understanding.

analyzed: tat avalokya asya kāruṇyam udapādi
translated: Seeing that, compassion arose in him.

original: aho khalv idaṃ jagad anādikālasambaddhaṃ nisargād eva andhe tamasi vartata iti /
analyzed: aho khalu idam jagat anādi kāla sambaddham nisargāt eva andhe tamasi vartate iti
translated: Alas! This world, connected from beginningless time, dwells from the very beginning in blind darkness.

original: athāsau mahāyogī katham asya varākasya andhe tamasi vartamānasya viśvasyānugrahaḥ kārya iti samutpannakāruṇyo manasi cintām āpede /
analyzed: atha asau mahā yogī katham asya varākasya andhe tamasi vartamānasya viśvasya anugrahaḥ kāryaḥ iti samutpanna kāruṇyaḥ manasi cintām āpede
translated: Then that great yogi, having generated compassion in his mind, thought: How can I bestow grace upon this poor universe, which is immersed in blind darkness?

original: sap / evaṃ vicintayan āsurisagotraṃ brāhmaṇaviśeṣaṃ varṣasahasrayājinam adhikāriṇam
analyzed: evam vicintayan āsuri sagotram brāhmaṇa viśeṣam varṣa sahasra yājinam adhikāriṇam
translated: Thinking thus, he recognized a qualified brahmin of the Asuree gotra, who had been performing sacrifices for a thousand years,

original: avagatya brahmopadeśavidyayā atandrito bhūtvā vācam ity uvāca bho bho
analyzed: avagatya brahma upadeśa vidyayā atandritaḥ bhūtvā vācam iti uvāca bho bho āsure
translated: and, becoming diligent in the knowledge of teaching Brahman, he spoke these words: O, O

analyzed: ramase gṛhastha dharmeṇa iti

original: sa tam uvāca rame bho iti /
analyzed: sa tam uvāca rame bho iti

translated: The sage, thinking that his discrimination and detachment were not yet fully accomplished, went out. Again,

original: dvitīye varṣasahasre pūrṇe pratyāgatya tathaivābhyuvāca bho bho ramase
analyzed: dvitīye varṣa sahasre pūrṇe pratyāgatya tathā eva abhyuvāca bho bho āsure ramase
translated: after a second thousand years were completed, he returned and spoke as before: O, O are you enjoying

analyzed: gṛhastha dharmeṇa iti
translated: the duties of a householder?

original: sa tam uvāca rame bho iti /
analyzed: sa tam uvāca rame bho iti
translated: He replied, I am enjoying, sir.

original: athāsau mahāyogīndras tathaiva nirgamya tṛtīye varṣasahasre sampūrṇe abhyetyovāca bho bho ramase gṛhasthadharmeṇa iti /
analyzed: atha asau mahā yogi indraḥ tathā eva nirgamya tṛtīye varṣa sahasre sampūrṇe abhyetya uvāca bho bho āsure ramase gṛhastha dharmeṇa iti
translated: Then that great lord of yogis went out again. After a third thousand years were completed, he returned and said, O, O are you enjoying the duties of a householder?

original: sa tam uvāca na rame bho iti /
analyzed: sa tam uvāca na rame bho iti
translated: He replied, I am not enjoying, sir.

original: atha sa bhagavatā uktaḥ katham iti /
analyzed: atha sa bhagavatā uktaḥ katham iti
translated: Then he was told by the Blessed One, How is it?

analyzed: punar āha āsuriḥ duḥkha traya abhighātāt iti
translated: Again, Asuri said, From the attack of the three kinds of suffering.

original: athāha kapilaḥ tāta utsahase brahmacaryavāsaṃ vastuṃ yadi tadāmīṣāṃ duḥkhatrayāṇāṃ pratīkāraṃ vayam upadekṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: atha āha kapilaḥ tāta utsahase brahmacarya vāsam vastum yadi tadā amīṣām duḥkha trayāṇām pratīkāram vayam upadekṣyāmaḥ
translated: Then Kapila said, Dear one, if you are able to live the life of celibacy, then we will teach you the remedy for these three kinds of suffering.

original: so 'bravīt bhagavan bāḍhaṃ śakto 'haṃ bhagavatām ādeśam anugantum iti /
analyzed: saḥ bravīt bhagavan bāḍham śaktaḥ ham bhagavatām ādeśam anugantum iti
translated: He said, Blessed One, indeed I am able to follow the Blessed One's instruction.

original: sa evaṃ gṛhasthadharmam apahāya putradārādikaṃ ca /

translated: Thus, having abandoned the duties of a householder and his son, wife, and so on,

original: pravrajito bhagavataḥ kila kapilācāryasya yoginaḥ prāṇāḥ /

analyzed: tatra ayam prativādaḥ

analyzed: duḥkha traya abhighātāt jijñāsā samutpannā  kam iha param  kim yāthātmyam
translated: The inquiry arose from the attack of the three kinds of suffering.🔽What is the highest here?🔽What is the essence?

analyzed: kim niḥśreyasam
translated: What is the highest good?

original: kiṃ kṛtvā kṛtārthaḥ syām iti matvāsau gurukulam abhigata iti / tathā hi
analyzed: kim kṛtvā kṛtārthaḥ syām iti matvā asau guru kulam abhigataḥ iti tathā hi
translated: Thinking, Having done what, would I be successful? he went to the teacher's house. Indeed,

analyzed: tat tapaḥ sa japaḥ sā dhīḥ tat jñānam sā ca vaiduṣī
translated: That austerity, that recitation, that understanding, that knowledge, that wisdom,

analyzed: iti śravaṇāt
translated: Thus it is heard.

analyzed: kim ca
translated: And further,

original: ihopapattir mama kena karmaṇā kva ca prayātavyam ito bhavād iti /

translated: By what action is my rebirth here? And where shall I go from this existence?

analyzed: vicāraṇā yasya na jāyate kṣitau katham sa dharma pravaṇaḥ bhaviṣyati

analyzed: tasmāt samīcīnam idam yat asya iti jijñāsā samudapādi
translated: Therefore, this is correct: that his desire to know arose.

analyzed: kim punar tat duḥkha trayam
translated: But what is that triad of suffering?

analyzed: tat āha ādhyātmikam  ādhibhautikam
translated: He says that: internal,🔽external,

analyzed: ādhidaivikam
translated: and divine.

analyzed: tatra prathamam dvividham
translated: There, the first is of two kinds.

analyzed: śārīram mānasam ca
translated: Physical and mental.

original: tatra śārīraṃ vātapittaśleṣmaṇāṃ dehadhātūnāṃ vaiṣamyād yad duḥkham ātmānaṃ deham adhikṛtya jvarātīsārādi pravartate /
analyzed: tatra śārīram vāta pitta śleṣmaṇām deha dhātūnām vaiṣamyāt yat duḥkham ātmānam deham adhikṛtya jvara atīsāra ādi pravartate
translated: There, the physical suffering that arises from the imbalance of the bodily constituents of wind, bile, and phlegm, which occurs with regard to the body, the self, and is called fever, diarrhea, etc.

analyzed: mānasam priya viyogāt apriya saṃyogāt ca dvividham
translated: The mental is of two kinds, from separation from what is dear and from union with what is not dear.

analyzed: etat ādhyātmikam duḥkham abhihitam
translated: This is said to be internal suffering.

original: ādhibhautikaṃ tu bhūtāny adhikṛtya yat pravartate mānuṣapaśupakṣisarīsṛpasthāvaranimittam /
analyzed: ādhibhautikam tu bhūtāni adhikṛtya yat pravartate mānuṣa paśu pakṣi sarīsṛpa sthāvara nimittam
translated: But that which occurs with reference to the elements is that which occurs for the sake of humans, animals, birds, reptiles, and plants.

original: ādhidaivikaṃ tu divam adhikṛtya yat pravartate śītoṣṇavātavarṣādikam /
analyzed: ādhidaivikam tu divam adhikṛtya yat pravartate śīta uṣṇa vāta varṣa ādikam
translated: But that which occurs with reference to heaven is that which occurs due to cold, heat, wind, rain, etc.

original: evam etais tribhir duḥkhair abhihatasyāsurisagotrasya brāhmaṇasya jijñāsā samutpannā /
analyzed: evam etaiḥ tribhiḥ duḥkhaiḥ abhihatasya āsuri sagotrasya brāhmaṇasya jijñāsā samutpannā
translated: Thus, the desire to know arose for the Brahmin Asurisagotra, who was afflicted by these three kinds of suffering.

analyzed: kva
translated: In which domain?

analyzed: tad abhighātake hetau
translated: In the cause that counteracts them.

original: teṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ duḥkhānām abhighātako vināśako yo 'sau hetus tatra /
analyzed: teṣām trayāṇām duḥkhānām abhighātakaḥ vināśakaḥ yaḥ sau hetuḥ tatra
translated: In the cause that counteracts those three kinds of suffering, that which destroys them.

analyzed: tām jijñāsām āha
translated: He states that desire to know.

analyzed: kim amūni duḥkhāni vapuṣaḥ
translated: Are these sufferings of the body?

original: āhosvit tadvyatirikto 'sti kaścid anyaḥ puruṣo yasyemāni trīṇi duḥkhāni jāyante /
analyzed: āhosvit tad vyatiriktaḥ u sti kaścid anyaḥ puruṣaḥ yasya imāni trīṇi duḥkhāni jāyante
translated: Or is there some other person apart from that, to whom these three kinds of suffering arise?

analyzed: uta amīṣām pratīkāra upāyaḥ pi asti na vā
translated: Or is there also a means of countering them or not?

analyzed: yadi asti tadānīm tam eva āsthāsyāmaḥ
translated: If there is, then we will rely on that alone.

analyzed: na u ced prathama prāvṛḍāsāram ṣaṇḍha
translated: If not, then like a eunuch in the first monsoon rain,

analyzed: iva amūni nimīlita netrāḥ vayam soḍhāraḥ
translated: we will bear these with our eyes closed.

original: vṛścikādidaṣṭa eva viṣapratīkārāya jāṅgulikaṃ gaveṣayati no vā viṣabhavapīḍāsahaḥ /
analyzed: vṛścika ādi daṣṭaḥ eva viṣa pratīkārāya jāṅgulikam gaveṣayati no vā viṣa bhava pīḍā sahaḥ
translated: When bitten by a scorpion, one seeks an antidote for the poison, not because one is unable to bear the pain of the poison's effect.

original: evam asahyaduḥkhābhibhūtasyāsures tadabhighātake hetau jijñāsā samutpannā /
analyzed: evam asahya duḥkha abhibhūtasya asureḥ tad abhighātake hetau jijñāsā samutpannā
translated: In the same way, when an Asura is overwhelmed by unbearable suffering, the desire to know arises for a cause that will counteract it.

original: sa ca samutpannaduḥkhābhāvaṃ jijñāsus tatpratīkārakuśalaṃ bhagavantaṃ kapilācāryaṃ śaraṇam abhyupagataḥ /
analyzed: sa ca samutpanna duḥkha abhāvam jijñāsuḥ tad pratīkāra kuśalam bhagavantam kapila ācāryam śaraṇam abhyupagataḥ
translated: And that Asura, desiring to know the absence of suffering that has arisen, has taken refuge in the Blessed Lord Kapila, who is skilled in the means of counteracting it.

analyzed: ayam mad abhilaṣita duḥkha pratīkāra upāyam vakṣyati iti
translated: He will tell me the means of counteracting the suffering I desire.

original: nanu duḥkhebhya eva jijñāsā samutpannā kathaṃ teṣām evābhāvāya kāraṇatvam upayāti /
analyzed: nanu duḥkhebhyaḥ eva jijñāsā samutpannā katham teṣām eva abhāvāya kāraṇa tvam upayāti
translated: But if the desire to know arises from suffering itself, how can it become the cause of the absence of those very [sufferings]?

original: na hi janayitrīsakāśād utpannas tanayas tasyā eva vyāpādanaṃ kurute /
analyzed: na hi janayitrī sakāśāt utpannaḥ tanayaḥ tasyāḥ eva vyāpādanam kurute
translated: For a son born from his mother does not kill her.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

original: iha loke yady asmād utpadyate tat tasyāpi vipattikāraṇaṃ dṛśyate /
analyzed: iha loke yadi asmāt utpadyate tat tasya api vipatti kāraṇam dṛśyate
translated: In this world, whatever arises from something is seen to be the cause of its destruction.

original: yathā karkaṭako 'śvataro vā janayitryāḥ samutpannas tām eva vyāpādayati /
analyzed: yathā karkaṭakaḥ śvataraḥ vā janayitryāḥ samutpannaḥ tām eva vyāpādayati
translated: For example, a crab or a mule born from its mother kills her.

original: yad vā yathā kaścid āśīviṣaḥ śuṣkatṛṇabahulapradeśe sthitaḥ pratisarpaṃ dṛṣṭvā kruddhas tasya mukhaniḥśvāsanirgato vahnis tṛṇāni taṃ vāpi sarpaṃ 🔽dadāha /
analyzed: yat vā yathā kaścid āśīviṣaḥ śuṣka tṛṇa bahula pradeśe sthitaḥ pratisarpam dṛṣṭvā kruddhaḥ tasya mukha niḥśvāsa nirgataḥ vahniḥ tṛṇāni tam vā api sarpam  dadāha
translated: so, in the same way, the fire of knowledge, produced from the anger of the Self, which is the Supreme Lord, burns the entire mass of misery.

original: amunā nyāyena duḥkhebhya eva jijñāsā niṣpannā duḥkhānām evābhāvaṃ kariṣyatīty arthasaṅgatiḥ /
analyzed: amunā nyāyena duḥkhebhyaḥ eva jijñāsā niṣpannā duḥkhānām eva abhāvam kariṣyati iti artha saṅgatiḥ
translated: By this method, the inquiry is accomplished from miseries themselves, and will bring about the absence of miseries themselves. This is the connection of the meaning.

analyzed: atrā ucyate dṛṣṭe sā apārthā ced
translated: Here it is said: If it is purposeless when seen,

original: ced ity ayaṃ nipātaḥ śaṅkāyāṃ vartate /
analyzed: ced iti ayam nipātaḥ śaṅkāyām vartate
translated: this particle 'ce' is used in doubt.

analyzed: iha loke sakala samutpanna duḥkhānām pratīkāraḥ asti eva
translated: In this world, there is indeed a remedy for all the miseries that have arisen.

analyzed: kim tad artham kapila upasarpaṇena iti bhāvaḥ
translated: What is the purpose of approaching Kapila for that? This is the meaning.

analyzed: tam eva hetum dṛṣṭam darśayati
translated: He shows that very seen reason.

original: śārīrādhyātmikānāṃ jvarātīsārādisakalavyādhīnāṃ santy evāgadaṅkārā aṣṭāṅgāyurvedavido bhiṣajaḥ kāyaśalyaśalākāviṣonmādaklībajarākumāracikitsānipuṇāḥ
analyzed: śārīra ādhyātmikānām jvara atīsāra ādi sakala vyādhīnām santi eva āgadaṅkārāḥ aṣṭāṅga āyurveda vidaḥ bhiṣajaḥ kāya śalya śalākā viṣa unmāda klība jarā kumāra cikitsā nipuṇāḥ
translated: For physical and mental diseases such as fever, diarrhea, and all other illnesses, there are indeed physicians who know the eight branches of Ayurveda, who are skilled in treating bodily wounds, foreign bodies, poisons, insanity, impotence, old age, and pediatrics.

original: mānasasyādhyātmikatāpasya pratīkāraḥ priyavastusaṃyogād apriyasya dūrataḥ pariharaṇāc ca /
analyzed: mānasasya ādhyātmika tāpasya pratīkāraḥ priya vastu saṃyogāt apriyasya dūratas pariharaṇāt ca
translated: The remedy for mental and spiritual distress is the union with a beloved object and the avoidance of the unpleasant from afar.

analyzed: ādhibhautikasya tu grāma nagara ādi kalpanayā prahāṇa upapattiḥ
translated: But for the physical, there is the possibility of abandoning it by the conception of villages, cities, etc.

analyzed: ādhidaivikasya abhivāta yāta prāvaraṇa āvaraṇa ādibhiḥ
translated: For the divine, by avoiding strong winds, cold, heat, etc.

analyzed: atas tad abhighāta kāraṇāt kim kapila upasarpaṇena iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, what is the use of approaching Kapila, since that is the cause of its destruction? This is the idea.

original: tathā ca laukikānām ābhāṇakaḥ 🔽arke cen madhu vindeta kimarthaṃ parvataṃ vrajet /
analyzed: tathā ca laukikānām ābhāṇakaḥ  arke ced madhu vindeta kimartham parvatam vrajet
translated: And in this way, there is a saying of worldly people:🔽If one finds honey in the sun, why would one go to the mountain?

original: iṣṭasya līlayā siddhau ko vidvān yatnam āśrayet //
analyzed: iṣṭasya līlayā siddhau kaḥ vidvān yatnam āśrayet
translated: What wise man would undertake effort when the desired is accomplished effortlessly?

analyzed: atra ucyate na  na iti ayam pūrvapakṣa vākya niṣedhe

analyzed: na evam vācyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: It should not be said in this way.

analyzed: ekānta atyantataḥ bhāvāt
translated: Because of the complete and absolute absence.

analyzed: ekāntataḥ vaśyam tvad ukta hetubhiḥ na pratīkāraḥ
translated: And because the remedy is not absolutely certain by the reasons stated by you.

original: yataś cikitsakānāṃ suprayuktāgadānāṃ yathāśakti yatatām api kadācij janturp /
analyzed: yatas cikitsakānām su prayukta agadānām yathāśakti yatatām api kadācid
translated: And because sometimes a creature dies even when physicians, using well-prepared medicines, are trying to the best of their ability.

analyzed: vipadyate kadācid jīvati
translated: Sometimes it lives.

original: vaidyagṛhe 'pi vadhūputrakalatrabhrātṛpitṛpabhṛtīnām aparihāryamaraṇadarśanān nāyam aikāntikapratīkāra ādhyātmikasya /
analyzed: vaidya gṛhe pi vadhū putra kalatra bhrātṛ pitṛ pabhṛtīnām aparihārya maraṇa darśanāt na ayam aikāntika pratīkāraḥ ādhyātmikasya
translated: Because of seeing unavoidable deaths of brides, sons, wives, brothers, fathers, etc. even in a doctor's house, this is not a remedy that is absolutely certain for the internal.

analyzed: aparam na asau pratīkāraḥ
translated: Moreover, even if it were, it would not be a remedy at all.

analyzed: agadena nīrujīkṛtānām api jvara ādīnām punar katipaya divasaiḥ utpatti darśanāt

original: ataḥ sarvathā ātyantiko 'pi na dṛṣṭaḥ pratīkāra ādhyātmikaduḥkhāpanayane samarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas sarvathā ātyantikaḥ pi na dṛṣṭaḥ pratīkāraḥ ādhyātmika duḥkha apanayane samarthaḥ

analyzed: vasanta ādīnām apagatānām api punar āgamana vat

original: bhavanti cātra ślokāḥ 🔽punar dāhaḥ samutpannaḥ punar jātaś ca vepathuḥ /
analyzed: bhavanti ca atra ślokāḥ  punar dāhaḥ samutpannaḥ punar jātaḥ ca vepathuḥ
translated: And here are verses:🔽Burning again has arisen, shivering has arisen again,

original: bādhate ca punar hikkā jvaraś ca punar āgataḥ //
analyzed: bādhate ca punar hikkā jvaraḥ ca punar āgataḥ
translated: and hiccups and fever have come again.

analyzed: anyat ca
translated: And furthermore:

analyzed: puṣpita akṣaḥ śalākī ca kuṣṭhī kāya cikitsakaḥ
translated: Pushpitaksha, Shalaki, Kushthi, and Kayachikitsa,

original: pṛcchanti bālabhiṣajaṃ kathaṃ te dārakā mṛtāḥ //
analyzed: pṛcchanti bāla bhiṣajam katham te dārakāḥ mṛtāḥ
translated: ask the young doctor, How did those children die?

original: kiñ ca nāsti samyagdhātuparijñānanipuṇatayā bhaiṣajyam / tathā hi
analyzed: kim ca nā asti samyak dhātu parijñāna nipuṇa tayā bhaiṣajyam tathā hi
translated: And furthermore, there is no medicine due to skill in fully understanding the elements. Thus:

original: yāni kāni ca mūlāni yena kena ca peṣayet /
analyzed: yāni kāni ca mūlāni yena kena ca peṣayet
translated: Whatever roots there are, with whatever one should grind,

original: yasmai kasmai ca dātavyaṃ yad vā tad vā bhaviṣyati //
analyzed: yasmai kasmai ca dātavyam yat vā tat vā bhaviṣyati

analyzed: anyat ca kārya arthi jana dravya bhakṣaṇāya

original: svaśaktikhyāpanāya ca svalpam api rogaṃ purastād vardhayanti bhiṣajaḥ /
analyzed: sva śakti khyāpanāya ca su alpam api rogam purastāt vardhayanti bhiṣajaḥ

original: tataś ca kadācid asau teṣām evāsādhyatām āyāti / tathā ca
analyzed: tatas ca kadācid asau teṣām eva asādhya tām āyāti tathā ca
translated: And then sometimes it becomes incurable for them. As it is said:

analyzed: vaidya vaidya namaḥ tubhyam kṣapita aśeṣa mānava
translated: O physician, salutations to you, O destroyer of all human ailments.

analyzed: tvayi vinyasta bhāraḥ yam kṛtāntaḥ sukham edhate

analyzed: evam asau dṛṣṭena agada ādi hetunā

analyzed: eka a tantaḥ vaśyam
translated: He must be one-pointed.

analyzed: atyantataḥ sarvathā
translated: Completely, in every way.

analyzed: śārīrasya ādhyātmika duḥkhasya na pratīkāraḥ

analyzed: evam mānasasya api śabda ādi priya saṃyogāt api kadācid na nivṛttiḥ

analyzed: asya tu śiṣyasya aikāntikaḥ ātyantikaḥ ca duḥkha vyapagame hetuḥ iṣṭaḥ

analyzed: tasmāt yuktam tad artham guru upasarpaṇam iti

original: yady evaṃ tadā dṛṣṭavyatirekeṇāpy ānuśravikaḥ śrutipraṇītaḥ svargādisādhanarūpo yajñādir hetur astu /

analyzed: nāka pṛṣṭhe pi tāpa traya asambhavāt
translated: Because the three kinds of suffering are impossible even in the heavenly world.

analyzed: tatra aikāntikam ātyantikam vā anuśrave vede śrūyate
translated: There, the eternal or absolute is heard in the Veda.

original: guruṇoktaṃ paścād vedaṃ śṛṇvanti śiṣyā ity anuśravo vedaḥ /
analyzed: guruṇā uktam paścāt vedam śṛṇvanti śiṣyāḥ iti anuśravaḥ vedaḥ

analyzed: tatra bhavaḥ ānuśravikaḥ

analyzed: śrautaḥ yajña ādi rūpaḥ yam duḥkha traya pratīkāra hetuḥ ucitaḥ sti

analyzed: tarati pāpmānam

analyzed: tarati brahmahatyām yaḥ śvamedhena yajate

analyzed: iti

original: yac cainaṃ devāḥ punar apy āhuḥ p /

analyzed: kim nūnam asmān kṛṇavat arātiḥ kim u dhūrtiḥ amṛta martyasya

analyzed: ṛgveda saṃhitā    iti

analyzed: iha śrutau aikāntikam ātyantikam ca phalam śrūyate

analyzed: atra asya vyākhyā
translated: Here is the explanation of that:

analyzed: atas eva asmad nivāsasya nākaḥ iti abhidhānam

analyzed: kam iti sukha nāma

analyzed: tasya niṣedhaḥ akam asukham tat naḥ iti na akam
translated: Nakam is the negation of that, i.e. it is not without happiness.

analyzed: kevalam sukham eva
translated: It is only pure happiness.

analyzed: dvau nañau prakṛtam artham gamayataḥ
translated: Two negative particles convey the intended meaning.

analyzed: tatas prāha indraḥ katham iti
translated: Then Indra asked: How is it?

original: tatas te ūcuḥ anena hetunā apāma pītavantaḥ /
analyzed: tatas te ūcuḥ anena hetunā apāma pītavantaḥ

analyzed: somam yajñe soma rasam

analyzed: anyat ca avidāma jānīmaḥ devān

analyzed: asmin svarge iyantaḥ devāḥ iti vidmaḥ

analyzed: aśvamedhasya vacanāt ūnāni paśubhiḥ tribhiḥ

original: paśuvadho 'gniṣṭome mānuṣavadhaḥ gosavavyavasthā sautrāmaṇyāṃ surāpānaṃ raṇḍayā saha svecchālāpaś ca ṛtvijām /
analyzed: paśu vadhaḥ gniṣṭome mānuṣa vadhaḥ gosava vyavasthā sautrāmaṇyām surā pānam raṇḍayā saha svecchā ālāpaḥ ca ṛtvijām
translated: Animal slaughter in the Agnistoma, human slaughter in the Gosava sacrifice, drinking of liquor in the Sautrāmaṇī, and the priests speaking freely with a prostitute.

analyzed: kalpasūtre api akṛtyam bhūri kartavya tayā upadiśyate

analyzed: brahmaṇe brāhmaṇam ālabheta kṣatrāya rājanyam marudbhyaḥ vaiśyam tapase taskaram nārakāya vīra haṇam taittirīyabrāhmaṇa
translated: One should offer a Brahmin to Brahman, a Rājanya to the Kshatriya, a Vaisya to the Maruts, a thief to austerity, and a killer of heroes to hell. Taittiriya Brāhmaṇa

analyzed: āpastamba śrautasūtra

analyzed: kim ca

translated: And for others, there is falling due to the enjoyment of karma.

original: ekāhādīnāṃ satrāṇāṃ dinaparimāṇavatāṃ kāraṇānāṃ parimāṇavad eva svargādi kāryaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: ekāha ādīnām satrāṇām dina parimāṇavatām kāraṇānām parimāṇavat eva svarga ādi kāryam dṛṣṭam
translated: For sacrifices lasting one day etc., which have causes of a certain duration, the effect such as heaven is seen to be of the same duration.

analyzed: kāraṇa anugama tvāt kāryasya
translated: Because the effect follows the cause.

analyzed: parimāṇavat mṛd piṇḍāt parimāṇavān eva ghaṭaḥ syāt
translated: From a lump of clay of a certain size, a pot of the same size would result.

analyzed: evam ānuśravikāṇām phala parimāṇa tvāt punar kṣayaḥ
translated: Thus, for those who hear [the Vedas], there is destruction again due to the limited duration of the fruit.

analyzed: atiśaya yuktaḥ ca
translated: And it is associated with excess.

original: yathā āḍhyam avalokya daridrasya duḥkhaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yathā āḍhyam avalokya daridrasya duḥkham syāt
translated: Just as a poor person would suffer upon seeing a rich person,

analyzed: surūpam ca vīkṣya kurūpasya
translated: and an ugly person upon seeing a beautiful person,

analyzed: prājñam dṛṣṭvā mūrkhasya
translated: and a fool upon seeing a wise person,

original: tathā śatāpsarasaṃ svargiṇaṃ dṛṣṭvā pañcāpsarasas taṃ dṛṣṭvaikāpsaraso duḥkham utpadyate /
analyzed: tathā śata apsarasam svargiṇam dṛṣṭvā pañca apsarasaḥ tam dṛṣṭvā eka apsarasaḥ duḥkham utpadyate
translated: in the same way, upon seeing a heaven-dweller with a hundred celestial nymphs, the suffering of one with five celestial nymphs or one with one celestial nymph arises upon seeing him.

analyzed: evam ayam dṛṣṭa vat
translated: This is just as seen.

original: tad evam anyonyātiśayāt svarge 'pi duḥkham avyāvṛttam /
analyzed: tat evam anyonya atiśayāt svarge duḥkham a vyāvṛttam
translated: Thus, in this way, because of mutual superiority, even in heaven, suffering is not excluded.

analyzed: tasmāt
translated: Therefore,

analyzed: tad viparītaḥ śreyān
translated: the opposite of that is better.

original: tābhyāṃ dṛṣṭānuśravikābhyāṃ hetubhyāṃ viparīto visadṛśa aikāntika ātyantiko viśuddho 'kṣayo 'nantaphalaḥ kaivalyān niratiśayo hetuḥ sa śreyān
analyzed: tābhyām dṛṣṭa ānuśravikābhyām hetubhyām viparītaḥ visadṛśaḥ aikāntikaḥ ātyantikaḥ viśuddhaḥ kṣayaḥ nanta phalaḥ kaivalyāt niratiśayaḥ hetuḥ sa śreyān  /
translated: The opposite of those two, seen and heard, causes, is dissimilar, unique, ultimate, pure, inexhaustible, has infinite fruits, is better than the solitary, unsurpassed.

analyzed: praśasyaḥ
translated: It is praiseworthy.

original: kathaṃ punar asau bhavatīty āha vyaktāvyaktajñavijñānāt /🔽vyaktaṃ cāvyaktaṃ ca jñaś ca teṣāṃp /
analyzed: katham punar asau bhavati iti āha vyakta avyakta jña vijñānāt  vyaktam ca avyaktam ca jñaḥ ca
translated: How does it become so? He says: from the knowledge of the manifest, unmanifest, and the knower.

analyzed: trayāṇām vijñānāt anubhavāt
translated: The manifest, the unmanifest, and the knower, from the knowledge of those three, from experience.

original: bhavati hy asau avaśyaṃ phaladānād aikāntikaḥ /
analyzed: bhavati hi asau avaśyam phala dānāt aikāntikaḥ
translated: It becomes so, because it necessarily gives fruits, it is unique.

analyzed: prakṛti jñānāt ātyantikaḥ
translated: From the knowledge of nature, it is ultimate.

analyzed: yama niyama ādimat tvāt śuddhaḥ
translated: Because it has restraints and observances, it is pure.

analyzed: śarīrabhede punar anāveśya tvāt akṣaya phalaḥ
translated: Because it does not enter again after the dissolution of the body, it has inexhaustible fruits.

original: kaivalyād anuttaratvāc ca niratiśayaphalam iti vākyaśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: kaivalyāt anuttara tvāt ca niratiśaya phalam iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder of the sentence is: because it is solitary, it has unsurpassed fruits.

analyzed: tatra vyaktam buddhi ahaṅkāra indriya tanmātra bhūta bhedāt trayoviṃśatikam
translated: There, the manifest is twenty-three-fold, from the distinctions of intellect, ego, sense organs, subtle elements, and gross elements.

analyzed: avyaktam pradhānam
translated: The unmanifest is the primordial nature.

analyzed: vyakta utpatti kāraṇam
translated: It is the cause of the origin of the manifest.

original: na hy akāraṇaṃ kāryam ity asya siddhiḥ /
analyzed: na hi akāraṇam kāryam iti asya siddhiḥ
translated: For it is not established that an effect has no cause.

analyzed: jñaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: The conscious being is the Purusha.

analyzed: sannidhi sattā mātreṇa cumbakaḥ iva lohasya pravṛtti kāraṇam
translated: By its mere presence, like a magnet with iron, it is the cause of activity.

original: ataḥ pradhānasya jaḍasya pravṛttihetur ayam astīti siddhiḥ /
analyzed: atas pradhānasya jaḍasya pravṛtti hetuḥ ayam asti iti siddhiḥ
translated: Therefore, it is established that this is the cause of activity for Prakriti, which is inert.

analyzed: etāni pañcaviṃśati tattvāni vyakta avyakta jña saṃjñāni
translated: These twenty-five principles are known as Manifest, Unmanifest, and Knower.

analyzed: yad vijñānāt avaśyam sarvathā tāpa trayeṇa vimucyate
translated: By knowing them, one is certainly liberated from the three kinds of suffering.

original: nanv amīṣāṃ katidhā pravibhāga ity atrocyate caturdhā /
analyzed: nanu amīṣām katidhā pravibhāgaḥ iti atra ucyate caturdhā
translated: Now, it is said that they are divided into four categories.

analyzed: katham iti ced tat ucyate
translated: If it is asked how, it is said:

analyzed: mūlaprakṛtiḥ avikṛtiḥ mahat ādyāḥ prakṛti vikṛtayaḥ sapta
translated: The root Prakriti is not a modification. The seven, beginning with Mahat, are modifications of Prakriti.

original: ṣoḍaśakas tu vikāro na prakṛtir na vikṛtiḥ puruṣaḥ // //
analyzed: ṣoḍaśakaḥ tu vikāraḥ na prakṛtiḥ na vikṛtiḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: The group of sixteen is a modification, not a Prakriti, not a modification. Purusha is not a modification.

analyzed: mūlaprakṛtiḥ pradhānam mūla bhūta tvāt
translated: The root Prakriti is Pradhana, because it is the root.

original: mūlaṃ saptānāṃ prakṛtivikṛtīnām ādir ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: mūlam saptānām prakṛti vikṛtīnām ādiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: It is the root of the seven Prakriti and Vikriti modifications. The meaning is that it is the beginning.

analyzed: prakaraṇāt prakṛtiḥ
translated: From the context, it is Prakriti.

analyzed: prasava dharmaka tvāt sā prakṛtiḥ
translated: It is Prakriti because it has the nature of producing.

analyzed: na vikṛtiḥ avikṛtiḥ anyasmāt anutpatteḥ
translated: It is not a modification, it is not modified, because it does not arise from anything else.

original: kāraṇam eva sā na kāryam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇam eva sā na kāryam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is only a cause, not an effect.

analyzed: anutpanna tvāt utpādaka tvāt ca
translated: Because they are not produced and because they produce.

original: mahadādyās tu sapta prakṛtayo vikṛtayaś ca /
analyzed: mahat ādyāḥ tu sapta prakṛtayaḥ vikṛtayaḥ ca
translated: But the seven, beginning with Mahat, are both evolvents and evolutes.

original: mahān ahaṅkāraḥ pañcatanmātrāṇi ceti sapta prakṛtayo 'nyeṣāṃ kāraṇatayā /
analyzed: mahān ahaṅkāraḥ pañca tanmātrāṇi ca iti sapta prakṛtayaḥ nyeṣām kāraṇatayā
translated: The seven, Mahat, Ahamkara, and the five Tanmatras, are evolvents of others, being the causes of others.

analyzed: vikṛtayaḥ ca kārya tayā svayam
translated: And they are evolutes, being effects themselves.

original: tatra vyaktim āha pradhānād buddhir iti vikṛtiḥ /
analyzed: tatra vyaktim āha pradhānāt buddhiḥ iti vikṛtiḥ
translated: Among them, Buddhi is said to evolve from Pradhana, and is an evolute.

analyzed: sā ca ahaṅkāram janayati iti prakṛtiḥ
translated: And it is an evolvent, producing Ahamkara.

analyzed: ahaṅkāraḥ mahataḥ utpannaḥ iti vikṛtiḥ
translated: Ahamkara is produced from Mahat, and is an evolute.

analyzed: tanmātrāṇi janayati iti prakṛtiḥ
translated: It is an evolvent, producing the Tanmatras.

analyzed: tanmātrāṇi ahaṅkārāt utpannāni iti vikṛtayaḥ pañca api
translated: The five Tanmatras are produced from Ahamkara, and are evolutes.

analyzed: tatas pañca mahābhūtāni jāyante iti prakṛtayaḥ
translated: From them, the five gross elements are born, and are evolvents.

original: utpannatvād utpādakatvāc ca saptamāḥ prakṛtayo vikṛtayaś ca /
analyzed: utpanna tvāt utpādaka tvāt ca saptamāḥ prakṛtayaḥ vikṛtayaḥ ca
translated: The seven are both evolvents and evolutes, because they are produced and because they produce.

analyzed: tanmātrāṇi śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandha ākhyāni
translated: The Tanmatras are called sound, touch, form, taste, and smell.

original: ṣoḍaśakas tu punar vikāra eva kāryatvāt /
analyzed: ṣoḍaśakaḥ tu punar vikāraḥ eva kārya tvāt
translated: But the group of sixteen is an evolute only, because it is an effect.

analyzed: na tu tasya prakṛti tvam akāraṇa tvāt
translated: It is not an evolvent, because it is not a cause.

original: tadvyaktim āha vaikṛtikād ahaṅkārād utpannāny ekādaśendriyāṇi tanmātrebhyaḥ pañcamahābhūtānīti
analyzed: tad vyaktim āha vaikṛtikāt ahaṅkārāt utpannāni ekādaśa indriyāṇi tanmātrebhyaḥ pañca mahābhūtāni iti
translated: He states their manifestation: the eleven sense organs arise from modified egoity, and the five gross elements from the subtle elements.

original: ṣoḍaśako 'yaṃ gaṇo vikāro 'nyasmād utpanno na hi tato 'nyad utpadyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: ṣoḍaśakaḥ yam gaṇaḥ vikāraḥ nyasmāt utpannaḥ na hi tatas nyat utpadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: This group of sixteen is modification, arising from something else. The meaning is that nothing else arises from it.

analyzed: utpanna tvāt anutpādaka tvāt ca
translated: Because it has arisen and because it does not produce anything else.

original: puruṣas tu punar na prakṛtir anutpādakatvāt na ca vikṛtir anutpannatvāt /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ tu punar na prakṛtiḥ an utpādaka tvāt na ca vikṛtiḥ an utpanna tvāt
translated: But the Purusha is not a primal substance because it does not produce anything, nor is it a modification because it has not arisen.

original: naivāsau kāraṇaṃ na ca kāryam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: na eva asau kāraṇam na ca kāryam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is neither a cause nor an effect.

analyzed: evam eṣa prakṛtiḥ
translated: Thus this is the primal substance.

analyzed: prakṛti vikṛtiḥ
translated: The primal substance and the modification.

analyzed: vikṛtiḥ
translated: The modification.

original: na prakṛtir na ca vikṛtir itibhedāc caturdhā prakṛtivikṛtivibhāgo 'bhihitaḥ // //
analyzed: na prakṛtiḥ na ca vikṛtiḥ iti bhedāt caturdhā prakṛti vikṛti vibhāgaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: Not the primal substance and not the modification. Thus, the division of the primal substance and the modification is stated in four ways due to the distinction.

original: eṣāṃ vyaktāvyaktajñānāṃ prameyāṇāṃ sādhanāya pramāṇāny āha /🔽pramāṇaprameyapramātṛpramitikrameṇa hi sakalasya siddhir dṛṣṭā /
analyzed: eṣām vyakta avyakta jñānām prameyāṇām sādhanāya pramāṇāni āha  pramāṇa prameya pramātṛ pramiti krameṇa hi sakalasya siddhiḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: For the proof of these objects, the manifest, the unmanifest, and the knower, he states the means of knowledge.🔽For the establishment of everything is seen to be by the sequence of the means of knowledge, the objects of knowledge, the knower, and the act of knowing.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam anumānam āpta vacanam ca sarva pramāṇa siddha tvāt
translated: Perception, inference, and the word of a reliable person are the three means of knowledge, because they are established by all means of knowledge.

original: trividhaṃ pramāṇam iṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhiḥ pramāṇād dhi // //
analyzed: trividham pramāṇam iṣṭam prameya siddhiḥ pramāṇāt hi
translated: The three-fold means of knowledge is accepted, for the establishment of the object of knowledge is from the means of knowledge.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam iti pratyakṣa paryāyaḥ
translated: The word seen is a synonym for perception.

original: akṣam indriyaṃ pratītya yad utpadyate jñānaṃ tat pratyakṣaṃ dṛṣṭam ucyate /
analyzed: akṣam indriyam pratītya yat utpadyate jñānam tat pratyakṣam dṛṣṭam ucyate
translated: The knowledge that arises in dependence on the sense faculties is called perception or seen.

original: yathā śrotrādīnāṃ śabdādayaḥ pañcendriyārthāḥ pañcānāṃ dṛṣṭaṃ pramāṇam /
analyzed: yathā śrotra ādīnām śabda ādayaḥ pañca indriya arthāḥ pañcānām dṛṣṭam pramāṇam
translated: For example, the five sense objects such as sound for the ear etc. are the five means of knowledge of the five [sense faculties].

analyzed: prathamam idam mukhyam sakala pramāṇānām
translated: This is the primary and foremost of all means of knowledge.

original: yo 'rtho 'munā dṛṣṭena sādhayituṃ na pāryate tatrānumānasyāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ rthaḥ munā dṛṣṭena sādhayitum na pāryate tatra anumānasya avakāśaḥ
translated: Where an object cannot be established by what is seen by this [perception], there is room for inference.

analyzed: tat ca tri sādhanam pañca sādhanam vā
translated: And that is either three-fold or five-fold.

analyzed: tri avayavam pañca avayavam iti apare
translated: Others say it is three-membered or five-membered.

analyzed: tat ca trayastriṃśat ābhāsa rahitam pratyakṣa abhāve pratanyate numānam
translated: And that inference, devoid of the thirty-three appearances, is extended in the absence of perception.

original: kam api hetum anvīkṣya tasya hetoḥ paścān mīyata ity anumānam /
analyzed: kam api hetum anvīkṣya tasya hetoḥ paścāt mīyate iti anumānam
translated: Inference is [so called] because after examining some reason, the existence of that [object] is inferred.

original: yathā dhūmaṃ hetum anvīkṣya mahānasa iva pūrvaṃ vahnidarśanād agner astitvaṃ sādhyata ity anumānam /
analyzed: yathā dhūmam hetum anvīkṣya mahānase iva pūrvam vahni darśanāt agneḥ astitvam sādhyate iti anumānam
translated: For example, just as the existence of fire is inferred in a kitchen after examining smoke as the reason, [so too in other cases].

original: pratyakṣānumānābhyāṃ yo 'rthaḥ sādhayituṃ na śakyas tatrāptavacanam /
analyzed: pratyakṣa anumānābhyām yaḥ rthaḥ sādhayitum na śakyaḥ tatra āpta vacanam
translated: Where an object cannot be established by perception or inference, there is [the means of knowledge called] the word of a reliable person.

analyzed: yathā svarge psarasaḥ santi
translated: For example, that there are celestial nymphs in heaven.

analyzed: nandanam vanam
translated: The Nandana forest.

analyzed: tatra viśeṣāḥ śabda ādayaḥ viṣayāḥ
translated: There, the specific objects are sound and so on.

analyzed: vimāne dhivāsaḥ iti
translated: The abode is in the celestial mansion.

analyzed: āptāḥ rāga dveṣa ādi rahitāḥ brahma sanatkumāra ādayaḥ
translated: The reliable persons are free from attachment, hatred, and so on, such as Brahma, Sanatkumara, and so on.

analyzed: śrutiḥ vedaḥ
translated: The scripture is the Veda.

analyzed: tābhyām upadiṣṭam tathā iti śraddheyam āpta vacanam
translated: The reliable statement is what is to be believed as it is taught by them.

original: nanv arthāpattiḥ sambhavo 'bhāvaḥ pratibhā aitihyam upamānaṃ cetiprabhṛtīni santi bahūni pramāṇāntarāṇi katham atra trividhaṃ pramāṇam iti
analyzed: nanu arthāpattiḥ sambhavaḥ bhāvaḥ pratibhā aitihyam upamānam ca iti prabhṛtīni santi bahūni pramāṇa antarāṇi katham atra trividham pramāṇam iti
translated: But there are many other means of valid knowledge such as presumption, possibility, non-existence, intuition, tradition, and analogy. How can there be only three means of valid knowledge here?

analyzed: atra ucyate sarva pramāṇa siddha tvāt
translated: To this it is said: because all means of valid knowledge are established by the three.

analyzed: sarvāṇi hi pramāṇāni pramāṇa traye viruddhāni
translated: For all means of valid knowledge are not contradicted by the three means of valid knowledge.

original: tatra pīno devadatto divā na bhuṅkta ity ukte rātrau bhuṅkta ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra pīnaḥ devadattaḥ divā na bhuṅkte iti ukte rātrau bhuṅkte iti arthaḥ
translated: There, when it is said that Devadatta is fat and does not eat during the day, the meaning is that he eats at night.

analyzed: sā arthāpattiḥ anumānam eva
translated: Presumption is just inference.

original: prastha ity ukte catvāraḥ kuḍavā iti bodhaḥ sambhavaḥ /
analyzed: prasthaḥ iti ukte catvāraḥ kuḍavāḥ iti bodhaḥ sambhavaḥ
translated: And when it is said prastha, the understanding is that there are four kudavas.

analyzed: sā u pi anumānam eva
translated: That too is just inference.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ ca prāk itaretara pradhvaṃsa atyanta abhāva bhedāt caturdhā
translated: And non-existence is of four kinds due to the distinction of prior, mutual, destruction, and absolute non-existence.

original: yathā vrīhiśoṣaṇadarśanān na vṛṣṭo deva iti vṛṣṭer abhāvaṃ sādhayati /
analyzed: yathā vrīhi śoṣaṇa darśanāt na vṛṣṭaḥ devaḥ iti vṛṣṭeḥ abhāvam sādhayati
translated: Just as seeing the drying up of rice does not establish the absence of rain, thinking The god did not rain.

analyzed: saḥ u pi anumāna bhedaḥ
translated: That is also a type of inference.

analyzed: pratibhā yathā
translated: Intuition is like

original: dakṣiṇena tu vindhyasya sahyasya tu yad uttaram /
analyzed: dakṣiṇena tu vindhyasya sahyasya tu yat uttaram
translated: To the south of the Vindhya and north of the Sahya,

original: pṛthivyām ā samudrāyāṃ sa pradeśo manoramaḥ //
analyzed: pṛthivyām sa pradeśaḥ manoramaḥ
translated: That region on earth up to the ocean is delightful.

original: ity ukte tatra śobhanā guṇāḥ santīti pratibhotpadyate /
analyzed: iti ukte tatra śobhanāḥ guṇāḥ santi iti pratibhā utpadyate
translated: When this is said, intuition arises that there are good qualities there.

analyzed: pratibhā jānatām jñānam
translated: Intuition is the knowledge of the wise.

analyzed: sā api anumānam eva
translated: That is also inference itself.

original: aitihyaṃ yathā asmin vaṭe yakṣiṇī prativasati iti janā vadanti ity ukte /
analyzed: aitihyam yathā asmin vaṭe yakṣiṇī prativasati iti janāḥ vadanti iti ukte
translated: Tradition is like people saying A yakshini dwells in this banyan tree. When this is said,

analyzed: sā vighnam karoti

analyzed: dhana ādi yacchati iti jñānam
translated: The knowledge that she grants wealth etc.

analyzed: tat api anumānam eva
translated: That is also inference itself.

original: upamānam yathā gaus tathā gavaya ityp /
analyzed: upamānam yathā gauḥ tathā gavaya
translated: Analogy is like The gavaya is like the cow.

analyzed: api anumānam eva
translated: That is also inference itself.

analyzed: kim ca tṛṣitasya añjalinā
translated: Moreover, from the thirsty one's cupped hands,

analyzed: kṣudhitasya pañca aṅguli yāgāt  pṛthula akṣi prabhṛti darśanāt durbalasya
translated: From the hungry one's offering of the five fingers,🔽From seeing the wide-eyed one etc., of the weak one,

analyzed: tarjanī paṅka darśanāt
translated: From seeing the threatening mudra,

analyzed: jñānam ityādi anumānam eva
translated: The knowledge etc. is inference itself.

original: tasmāt triṣv evānyad antarbhavatīti yuktam abhihitaṃ trividhaṃ pramāṇam /
analyzed: tasmāt triṣu eva anyat antarbhavati iti yuktam abhihitam trividham pramāṇam
translated: Therefore, it is correct to say that the other [means of valid cognition] are included in the three, and that the means of valid cognition are of three kinds.

original: iṣṭam iti abhipretam ity arthaḥ /🔽tena pramāṇena kiṃ sādhyam ity āha prameyasiddhiḥ pramāṇād dhi /
analyzed: iṣṭam iti abhipretam iti arthaḥ  tena pramāṇena kim sādhyam iti āha prameya siddhiḥ pramāṇāt hi
translated: Desired means intended.

original: yasmāt prameyaṃ sakalaṃ pramāṇena pramīyate yathā tulayā candanādi /
analyzed: yasmāt prameyam sakalam pramāṇena pramīyate yathā tulayā candana ādi
translated: By that means of valid cognition, what is to be accomplished? He says: The establishment of the object of valid knowledge is from the means of valid cognition, because the entire object of valid knowledge is cognized by the means of valid cognition, just as sandalwood etc. is by a scale,

analyzed: karṣa ādinā ghṛta ādi
translated: ghee etc. is by a karṣa etc.,

analyzed: prastha ādinā vā vrīhi ādi ityādi vat  pratyakṣa anumāna āgamāḥ pramāṇāni
translated: or rice etc. is by a prastha etc. and so on.🔽The means of valid cognition are perception, inference and scripture.

analyzed: prameyāḥ vyakta avyakta jñāḥ
translated: The objects of valid knowledge are the manifest, the unmanifest and the knower.

analyzed: pramātā ātmā
translated: The knower is the self.

analyzed: tatra trayoviṃśatikam vyaktam
translated: There, the manifest is twenty-three.

analyzed: avyaktam pradhānam
translated: The unmanifest is pradhāna.

analyzed: jñaḥ kṣetrajñaḥ
translated: The knower is the kṣetrajña.

original: tad amīṣāṃ madhye kiñcit pratyakṣeṇānyad anumānenetarad āptānumānābhyāṃ pramīyate /
analyzed: tat amīṣām madhye kiñcid pratyakṣeṇa anyat anumānena itarat āpta anumānābhyām pramīyate
translated: Among them, some is cognized by perception, some by inference, and the other by the inference of the trustworthy.

original: tasmād ācāryeṇa bhagavatā yuktam abhihitam prameyasiddhiḥ pramāṇād dhi iti // //
analyzed: tasmāt ācāryeṇa bhagavatā yuktam abhihitam prameya siddhiḥ pramāṇāt hi iti
translated: Therefore, it is proper for the teacher, the Blessed Lord, to say: The establishment of the object of valid knowledge is from the means of valid cognition.

original: tatra trividhasya pramāṇasya pṛthak lakṣaṇam upanyasyate /
analyzed: tatra trividhasya pramāṇasya pṛthak lakṣaṇam upanyasyate
translated: There, the separate definitions of the three kinds of means of valid cognition are presented.

analyzed: prati viṣaya adhyavasāyaḥ dṛṣṭam trividham anumānam ākhyātam
translated: Perception is the ascertainment of an object. Inference has been declared to be of three kinds.

analyzed: tat liṅga liṅgi pūrvakam āpta śrutiḥ āpta vacanam tu
translated: It is preceded by the mark and the marked, and the testimony of a trustworthy person is the statement of a trustworthy person.

original: viṣayaṃ viṣayaṃ prati yo 'dhyavasāyo netrādīnām indriyāṇāṃ pañcānāṃ rūpādiṣu pañcasu /
analyzed: viṣayam viṣayam prati yaḥ dhī avasāyaḥ netra ādīnām indriyāṇām pañcānām rūpa ādiṣu pañcasu
translated: Ascertainment of each object by the five senses such as the eye etc. with regard to the five objects such as form etc.

analyzed: tat pratyakṣam pratipatti rūpam dṛṣṭa ākhyam
translated: That is perception, having the form of apprehension, called seen.

analyzed: anumānam trividham
translated: Inference is of three kinds.

analyzed: tri sādhanam tri avayavam pañca avayavam iti apare
translated: Others say it has three means, three members, or five members.

original: tad ākhyātaṃ kathitam /🔽pakṣahetudṛṣṭāntā iti tryavayavam /🔽pakṣaḥ pratijñāpadam /
analyzed: tat ākhyātam kathitam  pakṣa hetu dṛṣṭāntāḥ iti tri avayavam  pakṣaḥ pratijñā padam
translated: That has been declared, explained.🔽The members are the proposition, the reason, and the example.🔽The proposition is the statement of the thesis.

analyzed: yathā vahnimān ayam pradeśaḥ
translated: For example, This place is fiery.

analyzed: sādhya vastu upanyāsaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: The proposition is the statement of the probandum.

analyzed: itare pakṣa ābhāsāḥ pratyakṣa viruddha ādayaḥ nava
translated: The others, such as the one contradicted by perception, are the nine fallacious theses.

analyzed: tri rūpaḥ hetuḥ
translated: The reason has three characteristics.

original: trairūpyaṃ punaḥ pakṣadharmatvaṃ sapakṣe sattvaṃ vipakṣe cāsattvam iti /
analyzed: trairūpyam punar pakṣa dharma tvam sapakṣe sattvam vipakṣe ca asattvam iti
translated: The three characteristics are: being a property of the subject, being present in similar instances, and being absent in dissimilar instances.

analyzed: atra udāharaṇam yathā dhūmavat tvāt iti
translated: An example here is because it has smoke, like that.

analyzed: anye hetvābhāsāḥ caturdaśa
translated: Others say there are fourteen fallacies of reasons.

analyzed: asiddha anaikāntika viruddha ādayaḥ
translated: Such as the unestablished, the contradictory, and the inconclusive.

analyzed: sādharmya vaidharmyābhyām dvividham nidarśanam
translated: An example is of two kinds, by similarity and by dissimilarity.

analyzed: yathā mahānasam
translated: Like a kitchen.

analyzed: itare nidarśana ābhāsāḥ daśa
translated: The other ten are fallacious examples.

analyzed: evam trayastriṃśat ābhāsa rahitam tri avayavam anumānam
translated: Thus, inference has three members and is free from the thirty-three fallacies.

analyzed: pañca avayavam iti apare
translated: Others say it has five members.

analyzed: tat āha avayavāḥ punar pratijñā apadeśa nidarśana anusandhāna pratyāmnāyāḥ
translated: He says: The members are the thesis, the reason, the example, the application, and the conclusion.

original: evaṃ pañcāvayavena vākyena svaniścitārthapratipādanaṃ parārthapratipādanaṃ parārtham anumānam /
analyzed: evam pañca avayavena vākyena sva niścita artha pratipādanam para artha pratipādanam para artham anumānam
translated: Thus, the statement of one's own ascertained meaning by a five-membered sentence is the inference for the sake of others, which is the statement of the meaning for others.

analyzed: tat ca trividham
translated: And that is of three kinds.

analyzed: pūrvavat śeṣavat sāmānyatodṛṣṭam ca
translated: Like the preceding, like the remainder, and seen in general.

analyzed: tatra viśiṣṭa megha unnati darśanāt bhavitrīm vṛṣṭim sambhāvayati
translated: There, from seeing the distinctive elevation of the clouds, one infers the rain that will occur.

analyzed: pūrvam iyam dṛṣṭā iti pūrvavat
translated: Because it was seen before in this way, it is like the preceding.

original: nadīpūradarśanād upari vṛṣṭo deva iti vā pratītiḥ /
analyzed: nadīpūra darśanāt upari vṛṣṭaḥ devaḥ iti vā pratītiḥ
translated: From seeing the flooding of the river, there is the understanding that it rained from the sky.

analyzed: śeṣavat yathā samudra udaka bindum prāśya
translated: Like the remainder, as when tasting a drop of ocean water.

analyzed: śeṣasya lavaṇa bhāvaḥ numīyate iti śeṣavat
translated: Because the saltiness of the remainder is inferred, it is like the remainder.

analyzed: sāmānyatodṛṣṭam puṣpita āmra darśanāt
translated: Seen in general, as from seeing flowering mango trees.

analyzed: anyatra puṣpitāḥ āmrāḥ iti
translated: Mango trees elsewhere are flowering.

original: punar yathā bahir udyota iti kenāpy uktaṃ /
analyzed: punar yathā bahis udyotaḥ iti kena api uktam
translated: Again, as it is said by someone: like light outside.

analyzed: tatra apareṇa api uktam
translated: There, it is also said by another:

analyzed: candraḥ uditaḥ bhaviṣyati iti artha saṅgatiḥ
translated: The moon will rise - this is the connection of the meaning.

analyzed: tat liṅga liṅgi pūrvakam iti
translated: That is preceded by the mark and the marked.

original: liṅgena tridaṇḍādidarśanenādṛṣṭo 'pi liṅgī sādhyate nūnam asau parivrāḍ asti yasyedaṃ tridaṇḍam iti /
analyzed: liṅgena tridaṇḍa ādi darśanena adṛṣṭaḥ liṅgī sādhyate nūnam asau parivrāj asti yasya idam tridaṇḍam iti
translated: By the mark, the seen three sticks, the marked, even though not seen, is proved. Surely that wandering ascetic exists, who has this three stick.

analyzed: āpta śrutiḥ āpta vacanam tu
translated: The word of the trustworthy person, but the statement of the trustworthy person.

analyzed: tṛtīyam pramāṇam
translated: The third is the means of knowledge.

analyzed: āptāḥ brahma ādayaḥ ācāryāḥ
translated: The trustworthy persons are the teachers such as Brahma.

original: śrutir vedas tad etad ubhayam āptavacanam /
analyzed: śrutiḥ vedaḥ tat etat ubhayam āpta vacanam
translated: The word of the trustworthy person is both the Veda and that.

original: āptiḥ sākṣādarthaprāptir yathārthopalambhaḥ tayā vartata ity āptaḥ sākṣātkṛtadharmā yathārthāptyā śrutārthagrāhī tad uktam āptavacanam /
analyzed: āptiḥ sākṣāt artha prāptiḥ yathā artha upalambhaḥ tayā vartate iti āptaḥ sākṣātkṛta dharmā yathārtha āptyā śruta artha grāhī tat uktam āpta vacanam
translated: Trustworthiness is the attainment of the object directly, the perception of the truth. It exists by that, therefore the trustworthy person is one who has realized dharma, who grasps the meaning heard by the attainment of truth. That is the statement of the trustworthy person.

analyzed: tatra api prasiddhi lakṣaṇā guṇa yogāt tisraḥ śabda vṛttayaḥ
translated: Even there, due to the connection with the quality characterized by well-known usage, there are three modes of verbal usage.

analyzed: tatra lakṣaṇā traividhyam
translated: There, the threefoldness of indication.

original: jahallakṣaṇājahallakṣaṇā jahadajahallakṣaṇā cetyādi pramāṇaśāstreṣu bahutaraḥ prapañca āste /
analyzed: jahat lakṣaṇā ajahat lakṣaṇā jahat ajahat lakṣaṇā ca ityādi pramāṇa śāstreṣu bahutaraḥ prapañcaḥ āste
translated: The extensive elaboration exists in the treatises on logic, such as the indication that abandons, the indication that does not abandon, and the indication that both abandons and does not abandon.

original: tatra prakrāntam eva tāvad abhidhīyate bhagavataḥ kapilasya matam /🔽āgamo hy āptavacanam āptaṃ doṣakṣayād viduḥ /
analyzed: tatra prakrāntam eva tāvat abhidhīyate bhagavataḥ kapilasya matam  āgamaḥ hi āpta vacanam āptam doṣa kṣayāt viduḥ
translated: Among them, the doctrine of Lord Kapila is first stated.🔽For, scripture is the word of a trustworthy person, and a trustworthy person is known to be one whose faults have been destroyed.

analyzed: kṣīṇa doṣaḥ vākyam na brūyāt hetu asambhavāt
translated: One whose faults have been destroyed would not speak falsely, because a reason for that is not possible.

analyzed: sva karmaṇi abhiyuktaḥ yaḥ rāga dveṣa vivarjitaḥ
translated: One who is engaged in his own duties, free from attachment and aversion,

original: pūjitas tadvidhair nityam āpto jñeyaḥ sa tādṛśaḥ //
analyzed: pūjitaḥ tadvidhaiḥ nityam āptaḥ jñeyaḥ sa tādṛśaḥ
translated: who is always honored by those like him, such a one should be known as a trustworthy person.

analyzed: tat evam etat trividham pramāṇam
translated: Thus, this is the threefold means of valid knowledge.

original: tad evaṃ vyaktāvyaktajñākhyasya pratyakṣāditrividhapramāṇeṣu kena kasya siddhiḥ syāt iti / atrocyate
analyzed: tat evam vyakta avyakta jña ākhyasya pratyakṣa ādi trividha pramāṇeṣu kena kasya siddhiḥ syāt iti atra ucyate
translated: Thus, in the three kinds of means of valid knowledge such as perception, etc., by which of them is the establishment of the manifest, unmanifest, and the knower to be known? To this it is said:

original: sāmānyatas tu dṛṣṭād atīndriyāṇāṃ pratītir anumānāt /
analyzed: sāmānyatas tu dṛṣṭāt atīndriyāṇām pratītiḥ anumānāt
translated: But the knowledge of supersensible objects is from inference based on what is seen in general.

original: tasmād api cāsiddhaṃ parokṣam āptāgamāt sādhyam // //
analyzed: tasmāt api ca asiddham parokṣam āpta āgamāt sādhyam
translated: And even from that, what is not established, the imperceptible, is to be inferred from the trustworthy scripture.

original: atra pradhānapuruṣāv atīndriyau tayoḥ sāmānyatodṛṣṭād anumānāt siddhiḥ /
analyzed: atra pradhāna puruṣau atīndriyau tayoḥ sāmānyatodṛṣṭāt anumānāt siddhiḥ
translated: Here, the primordial matter and the spirit are supersensible. Their establishment is from inference based on what is seen in general.

original: yasmān mahadādi liṅgaṃ triguṇaṃ dṛṣṭvā kāryaṃ tatkāraṇam adṛṣṭam apy asti triguṇaṃ ceti sādhyate pradhānam /
analyzed: yasmāt mahat ādi liṅgam triguṇam dṛṣṭvā kāryam tad kāraṇam adṛṣṭam api asti triguṇam ca iti sādhyate pradhānam
translated: Because having seen the effect, such as intellect, etc., which is the mark, as consisting of the three constituent qualities, it is inferred that its cause, though not seen, also exists and consists of the three constituent qualities. Thus primordial matter is inferred.

original: na hy asataḥ sadutpattiḥ syād iti /
analyzed: na hi asataḥ sat utpattiḥ syāt iti
translated: For an existent effect cannot arise from a non-existent cause.

original: na ca kāraṇāsadṛśaṃ kāryaṃ syād iti /
analyzed: na ca kāraṇā sadṛśam kāryam syāt iti
translated: And the effect cannot be unlike the cause.

original: vyaktaṃ tu pratyakṣeṇaiva sādhitam iti tadarthe na prayatnaḥ /
analyzed: vyaktam tu pratyakṣeṇa eva sādhitam iti tad arthe na prayatnaḥ
translated: But the manifest is clearly established by perception itself. Therefore, no effort is made for its sake.

original: yasmāj jaḍam api pradhānaṃ prasūtikriyāyāṃ pravartate tasmād asti lohasya calanakriyāśaktihetucumbakavad avaśyaṃ puruṣa iti jñasiddhiḥ //
analyzed: yasmāt jaḍam api pradhānam prasūti kriyāyām pravartate tasmāt asti lohasya calana kriyā śakti hetu cumbaka vat avaśyam puruṣaḥ iti jña siddhiḥ
translated: Since even the insentient pradhāna operates in the act of producing, therefore there must necessarily be a puruṣa, like a magnet, as the cause of the power of motion in iron. Thus the existence of the knower is established.

original: nanu pratyakṣeṇa yo 'rtho nopalabhyate sa sarvathā nāstīti mataṃ saṅgacchate /
analyzed: nanu pratyakṣeṇa yaḥ rthaḥ nā upalabhyate sa sarvathā nā asti iti matam saṅgacchate
translated: But it is reasonable to think that an object which is not perceived by perception does not exist at all.

analyzed: yathā dvitīyam anīśvara śiraḥ
translated: Like a second head of a non-existent god.

analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ bāhuḥ
translated: A third arm.

analyzed: vā
translated: Or like the horns of a rabbit, etc.

original: evaṃ pradhānapuruṣau nopalabhyete tasmāt tāv api na sta ity āśaṅkānirāsāyāha 🔽atidūrāt sāmīpyād indriyaghātān mano'navasthānāt /
analyzed: evam pradhāna puruṣau na upalabhyete tasmāt tau api na staḥ iti āśaṅkā nirāsāya āha  ati dūrāt sāmīpyāt indriya ghātāt manaḥ navasthānāt
translated: In the same way, the pradhāna and the puruṣas are not perceived. Therefore, they also do not exist. To remove this doubt, he says:🔽Due to being too far away, too close, a defect in the sense organ, a lack of attention,

analyzed: saukṣmyāt vyavadhānāt abhibhavāt samāna abhihārāt ca
translated: subtlety, obstruction, suppression, and being overwhelmed by something similar.

original: iha loke satām apy arthānām aṣṭadhā nopalabdhiḥ /
analyzed: iha loke satām api arthānām aṣṭadhā nā upalabdhiḥ
translated: In this world, even existent objects are not perceived in eight ways.

original: tathā hi darśayati yathā satām api devadattaviṣṇumitrayajñadattānāṃ deśāntaragatānām atidūrān nopalabdhiḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi darśayati yathā satām api devadatta viṣṇumitra yajñadattānām deśa antara gatānām ati dūrāt na upalabdhiḥ
translated: For example, even though Devadatta, Vishnu, Mitra, and Yajnadatta exist, they are not perceived when they are in another country or too far away.

analyzed: tat kim te na santi
translated: Are they then non-existent?

original: yathā vā cakṣur atisāmīpyāt kajjalaṃ nopalabhate /
analyzed: yathā vā cakṣuḥ ati sāmīpyāt kajjalam na upalabhate
translated: Or, the eye does not perceive collyrium due to its proximity.

analyzed: tat kim idam na asti
translated: Is it then non-existent?

analyzed: yathā badhira andhau śabda rūpe na upalabhete
translated: The deaf and blind do not perceive sound and form.

analyzed: tat kim te na staḥ
translated: Are they then non-existent?

original: anavasthitacittau rājānam api yāntaṃ na paśyati /
analyzed: anavasthita cittau rājānam api yāntam na paśyati
translated: One with an unstable mind does not see even a king moving.

analyzed: tat kim asau na gataḥ
translated: Has he then not gone?

analyzed: dhūma ūṣma truṭi nīhāra paramāṇavaḥ na upalabhyante
translated: The atoms of smoke, heat, sparks, and mist are not perceived.

analyzed: tat kim amīṣām abhāvaḥ
translated: Is their non-existence then possible?

analyzed: kuḍyena vyavahitam na upalabhyate
translated: What is obstructed by a wall is not perceived.

analyzed: tat kim na asti
translated: Is it then non-existent?

original: sūryāditejasābhibhūtānāṃ grahanakṣatratārakādīnām anupalambhāt teṣāṃ kim abhāvaḥ śakyate parikalpayitum /
analyzed: sūrya ādi tejasā abhibhūtānām graha nakṣatra tārakā ādīnām anupalambhāt teṣām kim abhāvaḥ śakyate parikalpayitum
translated: The planets, stars, and so on, overwhelmed by the light of the sun and others, are not perceived. Can their non-existence be imagined?

original: mudgarāśikuvalayāmalakamauktikakapotādinikurambe kṣiptaṃ samānaṃ yadi nopalabhyate tad avedam iti /
analyzed: mudga rāśi kuvalaya āmalaka mauktika kapota ādi nikurambe kṣiptam samānam yadi na upalabhyate tat ava idam iti
translated: If something thrown into a heap of beans, lotuses, jujubes, pearls, and pigeons is not perceived, is it then non-existent?

analyzed: tat kim na asti
translated: Is it then non-existent?

analyzed: evam aṣṭadhā satām api anupalambhaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: Thus, the non-apprehension of existing things has been stated in eight ways.

analyzed: idānīm asatām caturdhā bhavati
translated: Now, for non-existing things, it is of four kinds.

analyzed: tatra ucyate prāk pradhvaṃsa itaretara atyanta abhāva bhedāt
translated: There, it is said, due to the difference of prior non-existence, posterior non-existence, mutual absolute non-existence, and absolute non-existence.

original: tatra mṛtpiṇḍe ghaṭaḥ prāg utpatter nopalabhyata iti prāgabhāvaḥ /🔽pradhvaṃsābhāvo yathā mudgarābhighātāt pradhvasto ghaṭo nopalabhyate /
analyzed: tatra mṛd piṇḍe ghaṭaḥ prāk utpatteḥ na upalabhyate iti prāgabhāvaḥ  pradhvaṃsa abhāvaḥ yathā mudgara abhighātāt pradhvastaḥ ghaṭaḥ nā upalabhyate
translated: There, a pot in a lump of clay is not apprehended prior to its production, so it is prior non-existence.🔽Posterior non-existence is like a pot destroyed by the blow of a hammer, which is not apprehended.

analyzed: itaretarābhāvaḥ yathā aśve go tvam
translated: Mutual non-existence is like the absence of cowness in a horse,

analyzed: gavi aśva tvam
translated: and the absence of horsemanship in a cow.

analyzed: atyanta abhāvaḥ yathā dvitīyam anīśvara śiraḥ
translated: Absolute non-existence is like a second head of the Lord,

analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ bāhuḥ
translated: a third arm,

analyzed: śaśaviṣāṇa ādayaḥ vā
translated: or like the horns of a rabbit.

analyzed: evam iyam dvādaśadhā anupalabdhiḥ
translated: Thus, this non-apprehension is of twelve kinds.

analyzed: satām aṣṭadhā hi asatām caturdhā
translated: For existing things, it is of eight kinds, and for non-existing things, it is of four kinds.

analyzed: evam pradhāna puruṣau api santau na upalabhyete
translated: Thus, even the primordial matter and the souls, though existing, are not apprehended.

original: tad amīṣāṃ madhye kena hetunemau nopalabhyete / tad ucyate
analyzed: tat amīṣām madhye kena hetunā imau na upalabhyete tat ucyate
translated: Among these, by which reason are these two not apprehended? That is said:

analyzed: saukṣmyāt tad anupalabdhiḥ na abhāvāt kāryataḥ tad upalabdhiḥ
translated: Their non-apprehension is due to subtlety, not to non-existence. Their apprehension is due to effect.

original: mahadādi tac ca kāryaṃ prakṛtivirūpaṃ sarūpaṃ ca // //
analyzed: mahat ādi tat ca kāryam prakṛti virūpam sarūpam ca
translated: And that effect beginning with Mahat is of the form of the transformation of Prakriti and also of the form of Prakriti.

original: tasya pradhānasyānupalabdhir anavagamaḥ saukṣmyāt hetor nābhāvāt /
analyzed: tasya pradhānasya anupalabdhiḥ anavagamaḥ saukṣmyāt hetoḥ na abhāvāt
translated: The non-apprehension of that pradhāna is its non-understanding due to subtlety, not due to non-existence.

analyzed: sūkṣmam pradhānam śabda ādya lakṣaṇa tvāt paramāṇu ādi vat
translated: Pradhāna is subtle because it is not characterized by sound etc., like an atom etc.

analyzed: na punar evam
translated: But it is not like this.

analyzed: yat na asti pradhānam atas na upalabhyate
translated: That pradhāna does not exist, therefore it is not apprehended.

original: kiṃ tu asti pradhānaṃ nopalabhyate saukṣmyāt paramāṇvādivat /
analyzed: kim tu asti pradhānam na upalabhyate saukṣmyāt paramāṇu ādi vat
translated: Rather, pradhāna exists, but is not apprehended due to subtlety, like an atom etc.

analyzed: tarhi katham upalabhyate iti
translated: Then how is it apprehended?

original: atrāha kāryatas tadupalabdhiḥ /🔽p / kāryaṃ dṛṣṭvā kāraṇam anumeyaṃ vaṭadhānyavat /
analyzed: atra āha kāryataḥ tad upalabdhiḥ  kāryam dṛṣṭvā kāraṇam anumeyam vaṭa dhānya vat
translated: Here it is said: Its apprehension is through its effect.🔽Having seen the effect, the cause is inferred, like the banyan seed.

original: yathā vaṭadhānyaṃ kāraṇaṃ vaṭaṃ kāryam ālokyānumīyate /
analyzed: yathā vaṭa dhānyam kāraṇam vaṭam kāryam ālokya anumīyate
translated: Just as the banyan seed, which is the cause, is inferred by seeing the banyan tree, which is the effect,

original: evaṃ sad eva pradhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ mahadādeḥ sataḥ kāryād anumīyate /
analyzed: evam sat eva pradhānam kāraṇam mahat ādeḥ sataḥ kāryāt anumīyate
translated: in the same way, the existent pradhāna, which is the cause, is inferred from the existent effect, Mahat and the rest.

analyzed: na hi asataḥ sat utpattiḥ bhavati iti
translated: For an existent effect does not arise from a non-existent cause.

original: mahadādi mahāna haṅkāraḥ pañcatanmātrāṇi ekādaśendriyāṇi pañca mahābhūtāni ceti trayoviṃśatikam /
analyzed: mahat ādi mahāna haṅkāraḥ pañca tanmātrāṇi ekādaśa indriyāṇi pañca mahābhūtāni ca iti trayoviṃśatikam
translated: Mahat and the rest - Mahat, Ahamkara, the five Tanmatras, the eleven Indriyas, and the five gross elements - thus twenty-three.

original: etan mahadādi kāryaṃ triguṇaṃ dṛṣṭvānumīyate asti pradhānam api triguṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ yasyedaṃ triguṇaṃ kāryam iti /
analyzed: etat mahat ādi kāryam triguṇam dṛṣṭvā anumīyate asti pradhānam api triguṇam kāraṇam yasya idam triguṇam kāryam iti
translated: This effect consisting of Mahat etc. is seen to be possessed of the three Attributes. It is inferred that there must exist a cause also consisting of the three Attributes, of which this effect consisting of the three Attributes is the effect.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And what else?

original: tac ca kāryaṃ prakṛtivirūpaṃ sarūpaṃ ca /
analyzed: tat ca kāryam prakṛti virūpam sarūpam ca
translated: And that effect is dissimilar to and similar to the Primordial Matter.

analyzed: pradhānāt visadṛśam sadṛśam ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is unlike the Primordial Matter and also like it.

original: santi te hetavo yair etat pradhānaṃ visadṛśaṃ sadṛśaṃ ca /
analyzed: santi te hetavaḥ yaiḥ etat pradhānam visadṛśam sadṛśam ca
translated: There are those reasons by which this Primordial Matter is unlike and like.

original: yathā loke putraḥ pituḥ sadṛśo visadṛśaḥ syāt yadi rūpeṇa tadā na guṇaiḥ /
analyzed: yathā loke putraḥ pituḥ sadṛśaḥ visadṛśaḥ syāt yadi rūpeṇa tadā na guṇaiḥ
translated: Just as in the world, a son may be like his father and unlike him. If he is like him in form, then he is not like him in qualities.

original: yadā guṇais tadā na rūpeṇeti yāvat /
analyzed: yadā guṇaiḥ tadā na rūpeṇa iti yāvat
translated: When he is like him in qualities, then he is not like him in form, and so on.

analyzed: tān ca hetūn upariṣṭāt vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And we will state those reasons later.

analyzed: tiṣṭhatu tāvat etat
translated: Let this remain for now.

original: anyat pṛcchāmaḥ kim etan mahadādi prāg utpatteḥ pradhāne sat jāyate /
analyzed: anyat pṛcchāmaḥ kim etat mahat ādi prāk utpatteḥ pradhāne sat jāyate
translated: We ask another question: Does this Mahat etc. exist in the Primordial Matter before its origination and then come into being?

analyzed: uta asat sambhavati
translated: Or does it come into being from what does not exist?

analyzed: atra ācāryāṇām vipratipattiḥ atas saṃśayaḥ
translated: Here there is disagreement among the teachers, hence doubt.

original: atra vaiśeṣikā vipratipannā asataḥ sad bhavatīti manyante /
analyzed: atra vaiśeṣikāḥ vipratipannāḥ asataḥ sat bhavati iti manyante
translated: Here the Vaisheshikas disagree, thinking that what does not exist comes into existence.

original: mṛtpiṇḍe hi prāg utpatter ghaṭo nāstīti vyavasitāste /
analyzed: mṛd piṇḍe hi prāk utpatteḥ ghaṭaḥ na asti iti vyavasitāḥ te
translated: For they are convinced that a pot does not exist in a lump of clay before its origination.

analyzed: asti na asti iti varākāḥ jīvakāḥ
translated: The wretched living beings say, It exists or It does not exist.

analyzed: na eva asti na ca na asti
translated: It is neither existent nor non-existent.

analyzed: eṣa bauddhānām pakṣaḥ
translated: This is the position of the Buddhists.

original: evam anyonyavirodhavādiṣu darśiṣu ko nāma niścayaḥ /
analyzed: evam anyonya virodha vādiṣu darśiṣu kaḥ nāma niścayaḥ
translated: When there are teachers who speak of mutual contradiction like this, what certainty can there be?

analyzed: tat ucyate
translated: To that it is said.

original: tatra tāvat sadasadvādino jīvakāḥ svavacanavirodhenaiva nirastāḥ /🔽yadi sat tadāsan na bhavati /
analyzed: tatra tāvat sadasat vādinaḥ jīvakāḥ sva vacana virodhena eva nirastāḥ  yadi sat tadā asat na bhavati
translated: First, the living beings who speak of existence and non-existence are refuted by their own words contradicting themselves.🔽If it exists, then it is not non-existent.

analyzed: uta asat tadā sadbhāvaḥ na
translated: If it is non-existent, then it does not exist.

analyzed: yatas sat asatoḥ ekatra virodhāt
translated: Because existence and non-existence are contradictory in one place.

original: atra dṛṣṭānto yathā devadatto mṛto jīvati cetivat /
analyzed: atra dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā devadattaḥ mṛtaḥ jīvati ca iti vat
translated: The example here is like saying Devadatta is both dead and alive.

original: bauddhānāṃ tu nāsti na ca nāstīti pakṣaparigrahābhāvāt taiḥ saha sañjalpa eva na yujyate /
analyzed: bauddhānām tu na asti na ca na asti iti pakṣa parigraha abhāvāt taiḥ saha sañjalpaḥ eva na yujyate
translated: But for the Buddhists, there is no position of it is neither existent nor non-existent, so discussion with them is not appropriate.

original: vaiśeṣikāṇāṃ tu asataḥ sad bhavatīti matapratiṣedhāya ucyate
analyzed: vaiśeṣikāṇām tu asataḥ sat bhavati iti mata pratiṣedhāya ucyate
translated: But for the Vaiśeṣikas, to refute the view that the non-existent becomes existent, it is said:

analyzed: asat akaraṇāt upādāna grahaṇāt sarva sambhava abhāvāt
translated: Because the non-existent is not produced, because of the grasping of the material cause, because of the absence of the possibility of everything,

original: śaktasya śakyakaraṇāt kāraṇabhāvāc ca sat kāryam // //
analyzed: śaktasya śakya karaṇāt kāraṇa bhāvāt ca sat kāryam
translated: Because the capable produces the possible, and because of the existence of the cause, the effect is existent.

original: iha loke sad eva sad bhavati /
analyzed: iha loke sat eva sat bhavati
translated: In this world, only the existent becomes existent.

analyzed: asataḥ karaṇam na asti
translated: The non-existent is not produced.

analyzed: yadi syāt tadā sikatābhyaḥ tailam
translated: If it were, then oil from sand.

analyzed: kūrma romabhyaḥ paṭa prāvaraṇam
translated: A cloth made of tortoise hair.🔽The play of the eyebrows of the daughter of a barren woman.

analyzed: śaśaviṣāṇam
translated: The horn of a rabbit.

analyzed: kha puṣpam ca syāt
translated: And a sky-flower would exist.

original: na cāsti tasmād anumīyate pradhāne prāg utpatter mahadādikam asty eva /
analyzed: na ca asti tasmāt anumīyate pradhāne prāk utpatteḥ mahat ādikam asti eva
translated: And since that is not so, it is inferred that before the origination of the primary nature, the great one and so on do indeed exist.

analyzed: upādāna grahaṇāt
translated: Because of the grasping of the material cause.

original: iha loke yo yenārthī sa tadupādānagrahaṇaṃ karoti /
analyzed: iha loke yaḥ yena arthī sa tad upādāna grahaṇam karoti
translated: In this world, one who is in need of something grasps the material cause of that.

analyzed: tad nimittam upādatte
translated: He takes it up for that purpose.

analyzed: tat yathā dadhi arthī kṣīrasya upādānam kurute
translated: For example, one who is in need of curd makes the grasping of milk.

original: yadi cāsatkāryaṃ syāt tadā dadhyarthī udakasyāpy upādānaṃ kuryāt /
analyzed: yadi ca asatkāryam syāt tadā dadhi arthī udakasya api upādānam kuryāt
translated: And if the effect were non-existent, then one who is in need of curd would also make the grasping of water.

analyzed: na ca kurute
translated: And he does not do so.

analyzed: tasmāt pradhāne mahat ādi kāryam asti iti
translated: Therefore, the effect of the great one and so on exists in the primary nature.

analyzed: kim ca sarva sambhava abhāvāt
translated: And furthermore, because of the absence of the possibility of everything.

original: iha loke yad yasmin vidyate tasmād eva tad utpadyate /
analyzed: iha loke yat yasmin vidyate tasmāt eva tat utpadyate
translated: In this world, whatever exists in something, that arises from that itself.

analyzed: yathā tilebhyaḥ tailam
translated: For example, oil from sesame seeds.

analyzed: dadhnaḥ ghṛtam
translated: Butter from curd.

analyzed: yadi sa asatkāryam syāt tadā
translated: If the effect were non-existent, then everything

original: sarvataḥ sambhavet tataś ca tṛṇapāṃsuvālukādibhyo rajatasuvarṇamaṇimuktāpravālādayo jāyeran /
analyzed: sarvatas sambhavet tatas ca tṛṇa pāṃsu vālukā ādibhyaḥ rajata suvarṇa maṇi muktā pravāla ādayaḥ jāyeran
translated: would be possible from everything. And from that, silver, gold, gems, pearls, coral and so on would be born from grass, dust, sand and so on.

analyzed: na ca jāyante
translated: And they are not born.

original: tasmāt paśyāmaḥ sarvasambhavābhāvād api mahadādi kāryaṃ pradhāne sad eva sad bhavatīti /
analyzed: tasmāt paśyāmaḥ sarva sambhava abhāvāt api mahat ādi kāryam pradhāne sat eva sat bhavati iti
translated: Therefore, we see that even due to the absence of the origination of everything, the effect such as Mahat, etc. exists in Pradhana itself.

analyzed: atas ca asti śaktasya śakya karaṇāt
translated: And for this reason, there is the production of what is possible by what is able.

original: iha loke śaktaḥ śilpī karaṇādikāraṇopādānakālopāyasampannaḥ śakyād eva śakyaṃ karma ārabhate nāśakyam aśakyāt /
analyzed: iha loke śaktaḥ śilpī karaṇa ādi kāraṇa upādāna kāla upāya sampannaḥ śakyāt eva śakyam karma ārabhate na aśakyam aśakyāt
translated: Here in the world, a skilled craftsman who is able, being endowed with the means such as instruments, materials, time, and methods, undertakes only a possible task that can be done, not an impossible one that cannot be done.

original: tad yathā śaktaḥ kumbhakāraḥ śakyād eva mṛtpiṇḍāt śakyadaṇḍacakrasūtrodakavidalatalādibhiḥ sampanno ghaṭaśarāvodañcanādīny ārabhamāṇo dṛṣṭaḥ
analyzed: tat yathā śaktaḥ kumbhakāraḥ śakyāt eva mṛd piṇḍāt śakya daṇḍa cakra sūtra udaka vidala tala ādibhiḥ sampannaḥ ghaṭa śarāva udañcana ādīni ārabhamāṇaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: For example, a skilled potter is seen undertaking pots, dishes, water jars, etc. only from a lump of clay that can be made, being endowed with a suitable stick, wheel, thread, water, palm, etc.,

analyzed: na ca maṇika ādi
translated: and not from a gem, etc.

analyzed: aśakya tvāt tāvatā piṇḍena tasya
translated: Because that is impossible with just that lump of clay.

original: yadi punaḥ karaṇaniyamo na syād aśakyād apy aśakyam ārabhyeta /
analyzed: yadi punar karaṇa niyamaḥ na syāt aśakyāt api aśakyam ārabhyeta
translated: If again there were no restriction on the means, then even from what is impossible, what is impossible would be undertaken.

analyzed: tasmāt sat kāryam syāt na asat
translated: Therefore, the effect would be existent, not non-existent.

analyzed: kim ca kāraṇa bhāvāt ca
translated: And moreover, because of the existence of the cause.

analyzed: kāryam sat eva syāt
translated: The effect would be existent only.

original: iha loke yallakṣaṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ tallakṣaṇaṃ kāryaṃ syāt /🔽yathā kodravebhyaḥ kodravāḥ /
analyzed: iha loke yad lakṣaṇam kāraṇam tad lakṣaṇam kāryam syāt  yathā kodravebhyaḥ kodravāḥ
translated: Here in the world, the effect would have the same characteristics as the cause.🔽For example, from kodrava grains, kodrava grains would arise.

analyzed: vrīhibhyaḥ vrīhayaḥ syuḥ
translated: From rice grains, rice grains would arise.

original: yadi cāsatkāryaṃ syāt tadā kodravebhyaḥ śālīnām api niṣpattiḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca asat kāryam syāt tadā kodravebhyaḥ śālīnām api niṣpattiḥ syāt
translated: And if the effect were non-existent, then rice could be produced even from kodrava.

analyzed: na ca bhavati
translated: But it does not happen.

original: tasmāt kāraṇabhāvād api paśyāmaḥ pradhāne mahadādi kāryam astīti /
analyzed: tasmāt kāraṇa bhāvāt api paśyāmaḥ pradhāne mahat ādi kāryam asti iti
translated: Therefore, we see that the effect beginning with Mahat exists in the principal, even from the existence of the cause.

original: sādhitam evam etaiḥ pañcabhir hetubhiḥ sat kāryam /
analyzed: sādhitam evam etaiḥ pañcabhiḥ hetubhiḥ sat kāryam
translated: Thus, it has been established that the effect is existent by these five reasons.🔽This indeed, O Somya, was Being only in the beginning, one only, without a second. It thought within itself, Let me be many. Let me procreate myself. It sent forth fire.

original: sad eva somyedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyaṃ taddhaika āhur asad evedam agra āsīt ity ārabhya sattveva somyedam agra āsīt chāndogyopaniṣad
analyzed: sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam tat ha eke āhuḥ asat eva idam agre āsīt iti ārabhya sat tu eva somya idam agre āsīt chāndogya upaniṣad
translated: Thus, it is said in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad, beginning with This indeed, O Somya, was Being only in the beginning, one only, without a second.

analyzed: iti śruteḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the Upaniṣad.

original: tatra yad uktaṃ pūrvasyām āryāyāṃ prakṛtivirūpaṃ sarūpaṃ ca iti /
analyzed: tatra yat uktam pūrvasyām āryāyām prakṛti virūpam sarūpam ca iti
translated: There, what was said in the previous chapter - the manifest is both similar and dissimilar to the unmanifest -

original: tatsādharmyavaidharmyapratipādanāya idam ārabhyate 🔽hetumad anityam avyāpi sakriyam anekam āśritaṃ liṅgam /
analyzed: tad sādharmya vaidharmya pratipādanāya idam ārabhyate  hetumat anityam avyāpi sa kriyam anekam āśritam liṅgam
translated: this is begun in order to teach the similarity and dissimilarity.🔽The manifest is caused, non-eternal, non-pervading, active, multiple, dependent, with parts, and subordinate.

original: sāvayavaṃ paratantraṃ vyaktaṃ viparītam avyaktam // //🔽hetumad iti /
analyzed: sa avayavam paratantram vyaktam viparītam avyaktam  hetumat iti
translated: The unmanifest is the opposite of that.

analyzed: yasya utpatti kāraṇam asti tat hetumat
translated: Caused means that which has a cause of origination.

original: hetur apadeśo nimittaṃ prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam ity anarthāntaram /
analyzed: hetuḥ apadeśaḥ nimittam prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam iti anarthāntaram
translated: Cause, designation, reason, nature, and origination are synonyms.

analyzed: pradhānasya ete paryāya śabdāḥ
translated: These are synonyms for the primordial nature.

original: tasmāt pradhānena hetunā sakāraṇam idaṃ mahadādibhūtaparyantaṃ trayoviṃśatikaṃ liṅgam /
analyzed: tasmāt pradhānena hetunā sa kāraṇam idam mahat ādi bhūta paryantam trayoviṃśatikam liṅgam
translated: Therefore, this twenty-three-fold linga, beginning with Mahat and ending with the elements, is caused by the primordial nature as the principal cause.
