translated: In the same way, this puruṣa, who is present in the conflict of the various states of the guṇas, would be a mere witness due to his dissimilarity [to the guṇas].

analyzed: evam sākṣi tvam siddham asya puruṣasya
translated: Thus the state of being a witness is established for this puruṣa.

analyzed: kevala bhāvaḥ kaivalyam nāma tribhyaḥ guṇebhyaḥ
translated: Kevala-bhāva is kaivalya, which is being different from the three guṇas.

original: yathāsau bhikṣuḥ kadācin nāgarāṇāṃ vivadatāṃ vaktā bhavati tvayā sādhukṛtam iti tvayāsādhv iti /
analyzed: yathā asau bhikṣuḥ kadācid nāgarāṇām vivadatām vaktā bhavati tvayā sādhu kṛtam iti tvayā asādhu iti
translated: Just as that monk sometimes becomes the speaker of the disputing Nāgaras, saying You have done well or You have done badly.

analyzed: kim evam puruṣaḥ bhavati
translated: Is the puruṣa like that?

analyzed: atra ucyate mādhyasthyam
translated: Here it is said: neutrality.

analyzed: na asya kenacid kṛtyam asti
translated: He has nothing to do with anyone.

original: udāsīno hy ayam /🔽atrāha yady akartā tat kiṃ parakṛtānāṃ prayoktā /
analyzed: udāsīnaḥ hi ayam  atra āha yadi akartā tat kim para kṛtānām prayoktā
translated: For he is indifferent.

analyzed: atrā ucyate kartṛ bhāvaḥ ca dvividhaḥ hi
translated: Here it is said: The state of being an agent is of two kinds.

analyzed: prayoktā kartā ca
translated: The employer and the agent.

analyzed: atra udāsīnasya puruṣasya kartṛ tvam pratiṣiddham guṇa lakṣaṇena
translated: Here the state of being an agent of the indifferent puruṣa is denied by the definition of the guṇas.

original: atrāha yady akartā puruṣaḥ adhyavasāyaṃ tarhi kiṃ karoti dharmaṃ kariṣyāmy adharmaṃ ceti /
analyzed: atra āha yadi akartā puruṣaḥ adhyavasāyam tarhi kim karoti dharmam kariṣyāmi adharmam ca iti
translated: Here it is said: If the puruṣa is not an agent, then what does he do in regard to determination, that I will do dharma or I will do adharma?

original: yadi guṇā adhyavasāyaṃ kurvanti tarhi teṣāṃ sacetanatvaṃp / syāt /
analyzed: yadi guṇāḥ adhyavasāyam kurvanti tarhi teṣām syāt
translated: If the guṇas make determination, then they would have sentience.

analyzed: amīṣām ca acetana tvam eva prāk upanyastam
translated: And it has already been stated that these [mahat, etc.] are insentient.

original: atha puruṣo 'dhyavasāyaṃ kurute tadā tasya kartṛtvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: atha puruṣaḥ dhī avasāyam kurute tadā tasya kartṛ tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If the soul makes a determination, then it would follow that it is the agent.

analyzed: tasmāt ubhayathā api doṣaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is a fault in both cases.

analyzed: atra samādhīyate na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: Here it is resolved: This is not a fault.

analyzed: katham iti ced tat ucyate
translated: If it is asked how, it is said:

original: tasmāt tatsaṃyogād acetanaṃ cetanāvad iva liṅgam /
analyzed: tasmāt tad saṃyogāt acetanam cetanāvat iva liṅgam
translated: Therefore, the insentient linga, due to its connection with that [soul], acts as if it has consciousness.

analyzed: guṇa kartṛ tve pi tathā kartā iva bhavati udāsīnaḥ
translated: Even in the agency of the qualities, it becomes like an agent, indifferent.

analyzed: yasmāt cetana svabhāvaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: And because the soul has the nature of consciousness,

original: tasmāt tatsaṃyogād acetanaṃ mahadādi liṅgam adhyavasāyābhimānasaṅkalpālocanādiṣu vṛttiṣu cetanāvat pravartate /
analyzed: tasmāt tad saṃyogāt acetanam mahat ādi liṅgam adhyavasāya abhimāna saṅkalpa ālocanā ādiṣu vṛttiṣu cetanāvat pravartate
translated: therefore, the insentient linga, such as mahat, etc., acts as if it has consciousness in the activities of determination, conceit, volition, seeing, etc.

original: ko dṛṣṭāntaḥ tad yathā anuṣṇāśīto ghaṭaḥ śītābhir adbhiḥ saṃspṛṣṭaḥ śīto bhavati /
analyzed: kaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ tat yathā an uṣṇa aśītaḥ ghaṭaḥ śītābhiḥ adbhiḥ saṃspṛṣṭaḥ śītaḥ bhavati
translated: What is the example? Just as a pot, which is neither hot nor cold, becomes cold when touched by cold water,

analyzed: agninā saṃyuktaḥ uṣṇaḥ bhavati
translated: and becomes hot when in contact with fire,

original: evaṃ mahadādi liṅgam acetanam api bhūtvā cetanāvad bhavati /
analyzed: evam mahat ādi liṅgam acetanam api bhūtvā cetanāvat bhavati
translated: in the same way, the insentient linga, such as mahat, etc., becomes as if it has consciousness.

analyzed: tasmāt adhyavasāyam kurvanti guṇāḥ kārya ādiṣu
translated: Therefore, the qualities make determinations regarding effects, etc.

original: yad apy uktam lokopacārāt kartā puruṣa iti /
analyzed: yat api uktam loka upacārāt kartā puruṣaḥ iti
translated: And what was said, that the soul is the agent according to worldly convention,

original: atra brūmaḥ guṇakartṛtve 'pi tathā karteva bhavaty udāsīnaḥ /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ guṇa kartṛ tve pi tathā kartā iva bhavati udāsīnaḥ
translated: To this we reply: Even in the case of the qualities being the agents, the self is like an inactive agent.

analyzed: atra dṛṣṭāntaḥ ca
translated: And here is an example.

original: kecit kila caurā grāmaṃ hṛtvā dravyaṃ gṛhītvā grāmāntaraṃ gacchanti kṛtakāryāḥ /
analyzed: kecid kila caurāḥ grāmam hṛtvā dravyam gṛhītvā grāma antaram gacchanti kṛta kāryāḥ
translated: It is said that some thieves, having robbed a village and taken the wealth, go to another village, having accomplished their purpose.

original: taiḥ saha sārthena śrotriyo brāhmaṇaḥ panthānaṃ gacchati /
analyzed: taiḥ saha sārthena śrotriyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ panthānam gacchati
translated: A learned Brahmin travels the road with that caravan.

analyzed: tad pada anusāribhiḥ ārakṣibhiḥ te gṛhītāḥ
translated: The guards who follow their footsteps seize them.

original: kṛtāparādhais taiḥ saha so 'pi brāhmaṇo gṛhītas tvam api caura iti /
analyzed: kṛta aparādhaiḥ taiḥ saha saḥ u pi brāhmaṇaḥ gṛhītaḥ tvam api cauraḥ iti
translated: And the Brahmin is also seized along with those who have committed offenses, saying, You too are a thief.

original: tad yathāsāv acauras tatsaṃsargadoṣeṇa cauratayā pratītas taiḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā asau acauraḥ tad saṃsarga doṣeṇa caura tayā pratītaḥ taiḥ
translated: Just as that innocent man, due to the fault of association with them, is known as a thief by them.

original: tathā sattvādayo guṇāḥ kartāras taiḥ saṃyuktaḥ puruṣo 'pi akartāpi kartā bhavati /
analyzed: tathā sattva ādayaḥ guṇāḥ kartāraḥ taiḥ saṃyuktaḥ akartā api kartā bhavati
translated: In the same way, the self, though not an agent, becomes an agent by being associated with the qualities such as sattva.

analyzed: kartṛ saṃsargāt kartā iva
translated: Due to association with the agent, it is like an agent.

analyzed: param parama artha tayā akartā puruṣaḥ
translated: But the self is ultimately not an agent.

original: atrāha tasmāt tatsaṃyogāt iti pradhānapuruṣasaṃyoga iti cet /
analyzed: atra āha tasmāt tad saṃyogāt iti pradhāna puruṣa saṃyogaḥ iti ced
translated: Here it is said: If it is argued that therefore, due to that connection, it refers to the connection between the prakriti and the purusha.

analyzed: saṃyogaḥ kaḥ
translated: What is the connection?

analyzed: anekavidhaḥ hi saṃyogaḥ
translated: For there are many kinds of connections.

analyzed: anyatara karma jaḥ yathā sthāṇu śyenayoḥ
translated: One born from the action of one of the two, like that of a post and a dog.

original: sampātajo dvayor vā saṃyogo yathā dvyaṅgulākāśayoḥ /
analyzed: sampāta jaḥ dvayoḥ vā saṃyogaḥ yathā dvi aṅgula ākāśayoḥ
translated: The contact born of conjunction is like that of two spaces of two fingers' width.

analyzed: svābhāvikaḥ yathā agni uṣṇayoḥ  śakti hetukaḥ yathā matsya udakayoḥ
translated: The natural one is like that of fire and heat.🔽The one caused by potency is like that of fish and water.

analyzed: yādṛcchikaḥ suparnayoḥ vā ākasmikaḥ
translated: The accidental one is like that of a bird and the sky, or is spontaneous.

analyzed: atas saṃśayaḥ
translated: Therefore there is doubt.

original: atrocyate anyatarakarmajasaṃyogaś ca saṃyogo naiva pradhānapuruṣayor vibhutvāniṣkriyatvāt /
analyzed: atrā ucyate anyatara karma ja saṃyogaḥ ca saṃyogaḥ nā eva pradhāna puruṣayoḥ vibhu tva a niṣkriya tvāt

analyzed: atra ucyate

translated: Similarly, in other extremely urgent matters, the cessation of grasping due to impartiality in one's own place, that is non-stealing.

original: tathā strīpuruṣasaṃyoge parasparaliṅgasaṃyoge śabdasparśarasarūpagandheṣu yaḥ saṅgavyudāsaḥ śrotādyuparatiḥ asaṅkalpaś ca manasa uparatiḥ so
analyzed: tathā strī puruṣa saṃyoge paraspara liṅga saṃyoge śabda sparśa rasa rūpa gandheṣu yaḥ saṅga vyudāsaḥ śrota ādi uparatiḥ asaṅkalpaḥ ca manasaḥ uparatiḥ saḥ
translated: Similarly, in the union of man and woman, in the union of their respective organs, in sound, touch, taste, form, and smell, the avoidance of attachment, the cessation of hearing and so on, and the cessation of intention in the mind, that is

analyzed: ṣṭa aṅgam brahmacaryam
translated: the eight-limbed celibacy.

analyzed: evam hi āhuḥ saṃyoga śabda sparśa rasa rūpa gandha saṅkalpa smṛti dharma phala tyāga ādi aṣṭa aṅgam brahmacaryam iti
translated: For they say: The eight-limbed celibacy is the renunciation of the fruits of the union of sound, touch, taste, form, smell, intention, memory, and virtue.

analyzed: anyat ca
translated: And furthermore,

original: brahmabījaṃ retas tac carati na muñcatīti brahmacārī /
analyzed: brahma bījam retaḥ tat carati na muñcati iti brahmacārī
translated: the seed of Brahman is semen. He moves it and does not release it, thus he is a celibate.

original: brahma vedaṃ vā guruṇā pradattaṃ caratīti /
analyzed: brahma vedam vā guruṇā pradattam carati iti
translated: Or he moves the Veda or the knowledge given by the teacher, thus he is a celibate.

original: brahmā svayambhūs tasyāyaṃ daṇḍakamaṇḍaludhāraṇādirūpa ākāro brahmavac caratīti vā /
analyzed: brahmā svayambhūḥ tasya ayam daṇḍa kamaṇḍalu dhāraṇa ādi rūpaḥ ākāraḥ brahma vat carati iti vā
translated: Or, he is the self-existent Brahman, and this his form, consisting of the holding of the staff and water-pot, etc., moves about like Brahman.

original: evam arjanakrayavikrayādikalpanābhedānām anupādānaṃ sarvathā sarvasyāsvīkaraṇam aparigrahaḥ /
analyzed: evam arjana kraya vikraya ādi kalpanā bhedānām anupādānam sarvathā sarvasya asvīkaraṇam aparigrahaḥ
translated: Thus, non-acceptance is the non-appropriation of everything in every way, the non-acceptance of the various alternatives of acquiring, buying, selling, etc.

analyzed: iti pañca yamāḥ
translated: These are the five observances.

original: yaś cendriyāṇām antaḥkaraṇoparamas tac chaucaṃ bāhyaṃ mṛjjalādinā /
analyzed: yaḥ ca indriyāṇām antaḥkaraṇa uparamaḥ tat śaucam bāhyam mṛd jala ādinā
translated: And that cessation of the senses and internal organ is external purity by means of earth, water, etc.

analyzed: abhakṣya parihāraḥ tu saṃsargaḥ ca api a cintitaiḥ
translated: But the avoidance of what should not be eaten and also the avoidance of association with the unthinkable,

original: svadharme ca vyavasthānaṃ śaucam etat prakīrtitam //
analyzed: svadharme ca vyavasthānam śaucam etat prakīrtitam
translated: and the observance of one's own duty - this is declared to be purity.

analyzed: tathā yat bhaikṣa arjitena haviṣā prāṇa yātrā
translated: Similarly, the journey of life with the oblation earned by begging,

analyzed: ādhyātmikasya agneḥ mantra gṛhītena homaḥ kartavyaḥ
translated: the oblation should be offered with the mantra-received oblation to the internal fire.

original: ahany ahani yajñaśeṣāśanārtham etad āhāralāghavaṃ santoṣaḥ /🔽sa yāṃ prathamām āhutiṃ juhuyāt prāṇāya svāhāchāndogyopaniṣad / /
analyzed: ahani ahani yajña śeṣa aśana artham etat āhāra lāghavam santoṣaḥ  sa yām prathamām āhutim juhuyāt prāṇāya svāhā chāndogya upaniṣad
translated: This lightening of the diet is contentment for the sake of eating the remnants of the sacrifice every day.

original: ity ārabhya sa ya idam avidvān agnihotraṃ juhoti yathāṅgārān apohya bhasmani hutaṃjuhuyāt /
analyzed: iti ārabhya sa yaḥ idam a vidvān agnihotram juhoti yathā aṅgārān apohya bhasmani hutam juhuyāt
translated: He who would offer the Agnihotra without knowing this, as if he were to offer oblations after removing the coals into the ashes,🔽he would be a fool.

analyzed: tādṛś tat syāt chāndogya upaniṣad
translated: That is such, the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti śruteḥ
translated: Thus it is heard.

analyzed: tapaḥ kṛcchra cāndrāyaṇa ādi śarīra śoṣaṇa rūpam
translated: Austerity is of the form of emaciating the body, such as Kṛcchra, Cāndrāyaṇa, etc.

analyzed: viṣayāḥ vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ
translated: The objects of sense recede from the embodied one who does not eat.
Bhagavad Gītā.

analyzed: iti smaraṇāt
translated: Thus it is remembered.

analyzed: na atapasvinaḥ yogaḥ siddhi ati
translated: Yoga does not succeed for one who is not an ascetic.

original: anādivāsanāvicitrā pratyupasthitaviṣayajālā cāśuddhir nāntareṇa tapaḥ sambhedam āpadyata iti tapasa upādānam /
analyzed: anādi vāsanā vicitrā pratyupasthita viṣaya jālā ca aśuddhiḥ na antareṇa tapaḥ sambhedam āpadyate iti tapasaḥ upādānam
translated: Impurity, which is variegated with beginningless latent impressions and which consists of the net of present objects, does not come to an end without the breaking up of austerity. Therefore, austerity is taken up.

original: tac ca cittaprasādanam abādhamānam āsevyam iti manyante /
analyzed: tat ca citta prasādanam a bādhamānam āsevyam iti manyante
translated: And they think that that purification of the mind should be practiced without obstruction.

analyzed: svādhyāyaḥ praṇava ādi pavitrāṇām japaḥ
translated: Self-study is the repetition of the sacred texts beginning with the Praṇava.

original: īśvarapraṇidhānaṃ kriyāṇāṃ paramagurāv arpaṇaṃ tatphalasaṃnyāso vā /
analyzed: īśvara praṇidhānam kriyāṇām parama gurau arpaṇam tad phala saṃnyāsaḥ vā
translated: Surrender to God is the dedication of actions to the supreme guru or the renunciation of their fruits.

analyzed: iti anāśritaḥ karma phalam bhagavadgītā
translated: Brahma-offering, Brahma-oblation, Bhagavad Gītā.

analyzed: iti śravaṇāt
translated: Thus, because it is heard that one who is not dependent on the fruits of action Bhagavad Gītā.

original: ity amīṣāṃ yamaniyamādīnāṃ sevanāt ahiṃsāpratiṣṭhāyāṃ tatsannidhau vairatyāgaḥpātañjalayogasūtra /
analyzed: iti amīṣām yama niyama ādīnām sevanāt ahiṃsā pratiṣṭhāyām tad sannidhau
translated: Thus, by the practice of these restraints, observances, etc., non-violence becomes firmly established, and in its presence, the abandonment of enmity, Pātañjala Yoga Sūtra.

analyzed: ityādyāḥ siddhayaḥ
translated: And so on, are the accomplishments.

analyzed: vaiparītye tu vitarka bādhane
translated: But in the opposite case, in the suppression of discursive thoughts, there is the cultivation of the counteragent.

original: vitarkā hiṃsādayaḥ kṛtakāritānumoditā lobhakrodhamohapūrvakā duḥkhājñānānantaphalā iti pratipakṣabhāvanampātañjalayogasūtra /
analyzed: vitarkāḥ hiṃsā ādayaḥ kṛta kārita anumoditāḥ lobha krodha moha pūrvakāḥ duḥkha ajñāna ananta phalāḥ iti
translated: For discursive thoughts such as violence, which are done, caused to be done, or rejoiced in, preceded by greed, anger, and delusion, have the result of endless suffering and ignorance. Thus there is the cultivation of the counteragent.

original: p / evaṃ ca vartamānasya yoginaḥ sthānyupanimantraṇe saṅgasmayākaraṇaṃ punar aniṣṭaprasaṅgātpātañjalayogasūtra /
analyzed: evam ca vartamānasya yoginaḥ sthāni upanimantraṇe saṅga smayā akaraṇam punar aniṣṭa prasaṅgāt pātañjala yoga sūtra
translated: And thus, for the present yogi who is thus engaged, the non-attachment and non-amazement in the invitation of the residents is again due to the undesirable consequence.

analyzed: iti bhikṣoḥ ete yama niyamāḥ
translated: Thus, these are the restraints and observances for the mendicant.

original: ebhir yamaniyamair vā sādhyate sa dharmo vyākhyātaḥ /
analyzed: ebhiḥ yama niyamaiḥ vā sādhyate sa dharmaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: Or, by these restraints and observances, that dharma which is to be accomplished is explained.

analyzed: adhunā jñānam āha jñānam dvividham
translated: Now, he speaks of knowledge: Knowledge is of two kinds.

analyzed: bāhyam ābhyantaram ca
translated: External and internal.

analyzed: tatra bāhyam vīṇā paṇava gandharva citra kathā gaṇita vyākaraṇa śāstrāṇi
translated: There, the external is the musical instruments such as the lute and panava, the Gandharva stories, mathematics, grammar, and the scriptures.

analyzed: ābhyantaram guṇa puruṣa antara upalabdhi lakṣaṇam
translated: The internal is characterized by the perception of the difference between the qualities and the purusha.

original: anye guṇāḥ sattvarajastamāṃsi anyaḥ puruṣa iti /
analyzed: anye guṇāḥ sattva rajaḥ tamāṃsi anyaḥ puruṣaḥ iti
translated: Other qualities are sattva, rajas, and tamas, and the purusha is different from them.

original: bāhyena jñānena lokopapattir ābhyantareṇa mokṣa iti /
analyzed: bāhyena jñānena loka upapattiḥ ābhyantareṇa mokṣaḥ iti
translated: By external knowledge, there is worldly existence, and by internal knowledge, there is liberation.

analyzed: etat jñānam viṣaya uparamāt
translated: This knowledge is from the cessation of objects.

original: vairāgyam āha arjanarakṣaṇakṣayātṛptihiṃsādidoṣān dṛṣṭvā yo viṣayebhyo viraktas tasya mokṣo nāstīti /
analyzed: vairāgyam āha arjana rakṣaṇa kṣaya atṛpti hiṃsā ādi doṣān dṛṣṭvā yaḥ viṣayebhyaḥ viraktaḥ tasya mokṣaḥ na asti iti
translated: He states detachment: One who, having seen the faults such as acquisition, protection, destruction, dissatisfaction, harm, etc., becomes detached from the objects, for him there is no liberation.

original: ābhyantareṇa jñānapūrvakeṇa vairāgyeṇa mokṣo bhavati bāhyena saṃsāra iti /
analyzed: ābhyantareṇa jñāna pūrvakeṇa vairāgyeṇa mokṣaḥ bhavati bāhyena saṃsāraḥ iti
translated: Liberation comes from internal detachment preceded by knowledge, and worldly existence from external [detachment].

analyzed: aiśvaryam īśvara bhāvena iti aṣṭavidham
translated: Sovereignty is of eight kinds, as the state of a lord.

original: aṇimā laghimā garimā mahimā prāptiḥ prākāmyam īśitvaṃ vaśitvaṃ yatrakāmāvasāyitvam iti /
analyzed: aṇimā laghimā garimā mahimā prāptiḥ prākāmyam īśitvam vaśitvam yatra kāmāvasāyi tvam iti
translated: They are: aṇimā, laghimā, mahimā, iśitā, prāpti, prākāmya, eśitva, and vaśitva.

analyzed: etāni dharma ādīni catvāri sāttvika rūpāṇi buddheḥ
translated: These four qualities beginning with dharma are of the nature of sattva in the intellect.

original: yadā sattvena rajastamasī abhibhūte stas tadā sattvodriktaḥ pumān etān guṇān āpnoti /
analyzed: yadā sattvena rajaḥ tamasī abhibhūte staḥ tadā sattva udriktaḥ pumān etān guṇān āpnoti
translated: When sattva predominates over rajas and tamas, then a man endowed with increased sattva attains these qualities.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And what else?

analyzed: tāmasam asmāt viparyastam
translated: The tamasic [qualities] are the opposite of these.

original: asmāt sāttvikād dharmāder viparyastaṃ viparītam adharmājñānādyaṃ caturdhā buddhe rūpaṃ tāmasam /
analyzed: asmāt sāttvikāt dharma ādeḥ viparyastam viparītam adharma ajñāna ādyam caturdhā buddheḥ rūpam tāmasam
translated: The four forms of the intellect, beginning with adharma and ignorance, which are the opposite, the reverse, of these sāttvika [qualities] beginning with dharma, are tamasic.

analyzed: ye hiṃsā ādayaḥ vitarkāḥ ekāśīti bhedāḥ
translated: The thoughts beginning with harm, which are of eighty-one kinds,

analyzed: pṛthak daśa api yama niyama ādyāḥ
translated: and the ten separate [qualities] beginning with yama and niyama,🔽are all of the nature of rajas.

original: tathā adharmo 'jñānam avairāgyam anaiśvaryam ity aṣṭadhā sāttvikatāmasabhedā buddhiḥ /
analyzed: tathā adharmaḥ jñānam avairāgyam anaiśvaryam iti aṣṭadhā sāttvika tāmasa bhedā buddhiḥ
translated: Similarly, unrighteousness, ignorance, non-detachment, and non-sovereignty are the eight types of intellect distinguished as sāttvika and tāmasa.

original: asyā evam vidhāyā buddher ahaṅkāro jāyate // //
analyzed: asyāḥ evam vidhāyāḥ buddheḥ ahaṅkāraḥ jāyate
translated: From this kind of intellect, ego is produced.

original: idānīm ahaṅkārasya lakṣaṇaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ / tad ucyate
analyzed: idānīm ahaṅkārasya lakṣaṇam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ tat ucyate
translated: Now we will explain the definition of ego. That is said:

analyzed: abhimānaḥ haṅkāraḥ tasmāt dvividhaḥ pravartate sargaḥ
translated: Ego is self-conceit. From that, creation proceeds in two ways.

analyzed: aindriyaḥ ekādaśakaḥ tanmātra pañcakaḥ ca eva
translated: The group of eleven senses and the group of five subtle elements.

analyzed: abhimānaḥ haṅkāraḥ iti
translated: Ego is self-conceit.

original: rūpe aham rase aham gandhe aham /
analyzed: rūpe aham rase aham gandhe aham
translated: I am in form, I am in taste, I am in smell.

analyzed: aham vidvān
translated: I am learned.

analyzed: aham darśanīyaḥ iti evamādi abhimānaḥ haṅkāraḥ
translated: I am handsome. Such self-conceit is ego.

original: tasmāt abhimānalakṣaṇād ahaṅkārād dvividhaḥ pravartate sargaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt abhimāna lakṣaṇāt ahaṅkārāt dvividhaḥ pravartate sargaḥ
translated: From that ego characterized by self-conceit, creation proceeds in two ways.

analyzed: sargaḥ iti sṛṣṭeḥ paryāyaḥ
translated: Creation is a synonym for creation.

analyzed: kaḥ ca asau sargaḥ tat ucyate
translated: And what is that creation? That is said:

analyzed: aindriyaḥ ekādaśakaḥ
translated: The group of eleven senses.

analyzed: śrotra ādīni indriyāṇi manaḥ paryantāni
translated: The senses beginning with hearing up to the mind.

analyzed: tanmātra pañcakaḥ ca eva
translated: And the group of five subtle elements.

analyzed: tanmātrāṇi atra śabda ādīni gandha paryantāni
translated: The subtle elements here are sound and so on up to smell.

analyzed: evam ekādaśa indriyāṇi pañca tanmātrāṇi ca utpannāni
translated: Thus, the eleven sense organs and the five subtle elements have been produced.

analyzed: atra āha trividhaḥ haṅkāraḥ tam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ
translated: Here it is said: We will explain the three kinds of ego, beginning with that.

analyzed: tatra katarasmāt ahaṅkārāt indriyāṇi utpadyante
translated: Among them, from which ego do the sense organs arise?

analyzed: katarasmāt vā tanmātrāṇi iti atra ucyate
translated: Or from which do the subtle elements arise? It is said here:

analyzed: sāttvikaḥ ekādaśakaḥ pravartate vaikṛtāt ahaṅkārāt
translated: The eleven [sense organs] arise from the modified ego, which is of the sattva quality.

original: bhūtādes tanmātraḥ sa tāmasas taijasād ubhayam // //
analyzed: bhūtādeḥ tanmātraḥ sa tāmasaḥ taijasāt ubhayam
translated: The subtle elements arise from the ego of the great one, which is of the tamas quality. Both [the eleven and the five] arise from the ego of the luminous one.

analyzed: sāttvikaḥ iti
translated: Of the sattva quality means:

original: yadā sattvam utkaṭaṃ bhavati ahaṅkāre tena ca sattvena rajastamasī abhibhūte syātāṃ tadā sāttviko 'haṅkāra ucyate /
analyzed: yadā sattvam utkaṭam bhavati ahaṅkāre tena ca sattvena rajaḥ tamasī abhibhūte syātām tadā sāttvikaḥ haṅkāraḥ ucyate
translated: When sattva is predominant in the ego, and by that sattva, rajas and tamas are subdued, then that ego is said to be of the sattva quality.

original: tasya sāttvikasya vaikṛtika iti pūrvācāryaiḥ saṃjñā kṛtā /
analyzed: tasya sāttvikasya vaikṛtikaḥ iti pūrva ācāryaiḥ saṃjñā kṛtā
translated: That ego of the sattva quality has been given the name modified by the teachers of the past.

original: sa vaikṛtiko bhūtvā ahaṅkāra ekādaśendriyāṇi utpādayati /
analyzed: sa vaikṛtikaḥ bhūtvā ahaṅkāre ekādaśa indriyāṇi utpādayati
translated: That modified ego produces the eleven sense organs.

analyzed: tasmāt sāttvikāni imāni viśuddhāni sva viṣaya grahaṇa samarthāni bhavanti
translated: Therefore, these [sense organs] are pure and capable of grasping their own objects.

original: tasmād ucyate sāttvika ekādaśakaḥ pravartate vaikṛtād ahaṅkārāt iti /
analyzed: tasmāt ucyate sāttvikaḥ ekādaśakaḥ pravartate vaikṛtāt ahaṅkārāt iti
translated: Therefore, it is said: The eleven [sense organs] arise from the modified ego, which is of the sattva quality.

analyzed: bhūtādeḥ tanmātrāḥ
translated: The subtle elements arise from the ego of the great one.

original: bhūtādes tamobāhulyād gauṇībhūtasattvarajaso bhūtādināmnaḥ pūrvācāryair nirūpitād ahaṅkārāt tanmātraḥ śabdādipañcako gaṇo jāyate /
analyzed: bhūtādeḥ tamaḥ bāhulyāt gauṇībhūta sattva rajasaḥ bhūta ādi nāmnaḥ pūrva ācāryaiḥ nirūpitāt ahaṅkārāt tanmātraḥ śabda ādi pañcakaḥ gaṇaḥ jāyate
translated: From the egoity described by the ancient teachers as Bhūtādi, in which sattva and rajas are subordinate due to the predominance of tamas in the Bhūtas, the group of five subtle elements such as sound is born.

original: abhibhūtasattvatamaso rājasāt taijasābhidhānād ahaṅkārāt pravṛttikarmaṇa ubhayaṃ prakāśātmakam ekādaśendriyakaṃ mohātmakaṃ tanmātrikaṃ cāsīd
analyzed: abhibhūta sattva tamasaḥ rājasāt taijasa abhidhānāt ahaṅkārāt pravṛtti karmaṇaḥ ubhayam prakāśa ātmakam ekādaśa indriyakam moha ātmakam tanmātrikam ca āsīt
translated: From the egoity called Taijasa, which is dominated by rajas, both the group of eleven sense organs which is of the nature of light, and the group of subtle elements which is of the nature of delusion, arise, due to its active function.

analyzed: iti sambandhaḥ
translated: This is the connection.

analyzed: taijase eva rājase haṅkāre kriyāśaktiḥ asti
translated: In the Taijasa egoity which is of the nature of rajas, there is the power of action.

original: sattvaṃ niṣkriyam ekāki na śaknoty utpādayitum /
analyzed: sattvam niṣkriyam ekāki na śaknoti utpādayitum
translated: Sattva, being inactive and solitary, is unable to produce anything.

original: tamaś ca mūḍhatvād akriyam asamarthaṃ vinā rajaḥ sṛṣṭim utpādayitum /
analyzed: tamaḥ ca mūḍha tvāt akriyam asamartham vinā rajaḥ sṛṣṭim utpādayitum
translated: And tamas, being deluded and inactive, is incapable of producing creation without rajas.

original: ata ubhe sattvatamasī sṛṣṭiviṣaye rajasānugṛhīte aindriyakaṃ tānmātrikaṃ ca gaṇadvayaṃ janayata iti tātparyārthaḥ // //
analyzed: atas ubhe sattva tamasī sṛṣṭi viṣaye rajasā anugṛhīte aindriyakam tānmātrikam ca gaṇa dvayam janayataḥ iti tātparyārthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that both sattva and tamas, aided by rajas in the matter of creation, generate the two groups of sense organs and subtle elements.

original: tatra kāni buddhīndriyāṇi kāni karmendriyāṇīti / ucyate
analyzed: tatra kāni buddhīndriyāṇi kāni karmendriyāṇi iti ucyate
translated: Now, which are the organs of sense and which are the organs of action? It is said:

analyzed: buddhīndriyāṇi śrotra tvac cakṣuḥ rasana nāsikā ākhyāni
translated: The organs of sense are the ear, skin, eye, tongue, and nose.

analyzed: vāc pāṇi pāda pāyu upasthān karmendriyāṇi āhuḥ
translated: Speech, hands, feet, anus, and genitals are said to be the organs of action.

analyzed: śrotra ādīni buddhīndriyāṇi iti ucyante
translated: The ears and so on are called the organs of knowledge.

analyzed: śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhān buddhyante iti buddhīndriyāṇi
translated: They are called organs of knowledge because they know sound, touch, form, taste, and smell.

analyzed: indriyāṇi eva tāni indriyāṇi
translated: They are organs because they are organs.

analyzed: iti viṣayāṇām nāma
translated: In is the name of objects.

analyzed: tāninaḥ viṣayān prati dravantīti indriyāṇi
translated: They flow towards those objects, therefore they are organs.

analyzed: vāc pāṇi pāda pāyu upasthān karmendriyāṇi āhuḥ
translated: Speech, hands, feet, anus, and genitals are said to be the organs of action.

analyzed: karma kurvanti kārayanti ca
translated: They perform actions and cause others to perform actions.

analyzed: karmendriyāṇām vṛttiḥ
translated: This is the function of the organs of action.

analyzed: vāc vadati karma
translated: Speech performs the action of speaking.

analyzed: hastau grahaṇa karmāṇau  pādau viṣama sama nimna unnata bhū pradeśeṣu krāmataḥ
translated: The hands perform the action of grasping.🔽The feet walk on uneven, even, low, and high parts of the ground.

analyzed: pāyuḥ yathā bhukta anna udaka malam utsṛjati
translated: The anus expels food and water that has been eaten and drunk.

original: upastha ānandaṃ karoti putram utpādayatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: upasthe ānandam karoti putram utpādayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The genitals produce pleasure, which means it produces a son.

analyzed: evam etāḥ karmendriyāṇām vṛttayaḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: Thus the functions of these organs of action have been explained.

original: atrāha mana indriyaṃ tat kiṃ lakṣaṇam iti / atrocyate
analyzed: atra āha manaḥ indriyam tat kim lakṣaṇam iti atra ucyate
translated: Here it is said: the mind is an organ, what are its characteristics? Here it is said:

original: ubhayātmakam atra manaḥ saṅkalpakam indriyaṃ ca sādharmyāt /
analyzed: ubhaya ātmakam atra manaḥ saṅkalpakam indriyam ca sādharmyāt
translated: The mind here has a dual nature, it is an organ of imagination and an organ by similarity.

analyzed: guṇa pariṇāma viśeṣāt nānā tvam grāhya bhedāt ca
translated: The diversity is due to the specific modifications of the qualities and also due to the difference in the objects grasped.

analyzed: ubhaya ātmakam atra manaḥ
translated: Here, the mind has the nature of both.

analyzed: karmendriyeṣu karmendriyam
translated: Among the organs of action, it is an organ of action.

analyzed: buddhīndriyeṣu buddhīndriyam
translated: Among the organs of knowledge, it is an organ of knowledge.

original: yathā devadatto gopālamadhye sthito gopālatvaṃ kurute mallamadhye sthito mallatvaṃ kurute /
analyzed: yathā devadattaḥ gopāla madhye sthitaḥ gopāla tvam kurute malla madhye sthitaḥ malla tvam kurute
translated: Just as Devadatta, being in the midst of cowherds, acts like a cowherd, and being in the midst of wrestlers, acts like a wrestler.

original: kasmāt / yasmād buddhīndriyāṇāṃ vṛttiṃ saṅkalpayati karmendriyāṇāṃ ca /
analyzed: kasmāt yasmāt buddhīndriyāṇām vṛttim saṅkalpayati karmendriyāṇām ca
translated: Why? Because it conceives the functions of the organs of knowledge and action.

analyzed: tasmāt ubhaya ātmakam manaḥ
translated: Therefore, the mind has the nature of both.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And what else?

analyzed: indriyam ca sādharmyāt
translated: It is an organ because it has the same nature.

analyzed: sahadharmasya bhāvaḥ sādharmyam
translated: Sameness of nature means having the same qualities.

original: yasmāt karmendriyāṇi buddhīndriyāṇi ca sāttvikād ahaṅkārād utpadyante /
analyzed: yasmāt karmendriyāṇi buddhīndriyāṇi ca sāttvikāt ahaṅkārāt utpadyante
translated: Because the organs of action and the organs of knowledge arise from the Sāttvika ego,

analyzed: manaḥ pi tasmāt eva utpadyate
translated: the mind also arises from that same [Sāttvika ego].

analyzed: tasmāt indriyam manaḥ
translated: Therefore, the mind is an organ.

analyzed: tatra manasaḥ kā vṛttiḥ
translated: What is the function of the mind there?

analyzed: saṅkalpaḥ vṛttiḥ
translated: Imagination is its function.

analyzed: buddhīndriyāṇām śabda ādayaḥ vṛttayaḥ
translated: For the organs of knowledge, sound and so on are the functions.

analyzed: karmendriyāṇām vacana ādayaḥ
translated: For the organs of action, speaking and so on are the functions.

analyzed: evam ekādaśa indriyāṇi saha vṛttibhiḥ vyākhyātāni
translated: Thus, the eleven organs along with their functions have been explained.

original: atrāha ekādaśendriyāṇi kena kṛtāni puruṣeṇa īśvareṇa āhosvit svabhāveneti kuta iyam āśaṅketi cet /
analyzed: atra āha ekādaśa indriyāṇi kena kṛtāni puruṣeṇa īśvareṇa āhosvit svabhāvena iti kutas iyam āśaṅkā iti ced
translated: Here it is said: The eleven organs are made by some person, by God, or by nature. Why is this doubt raised?

analyzed: imāni ekādaśa indriyāṇi ekādaśa viṣaya grāhakāṇi bhavanti  tatra antaḥkaraṇa pradhāna buddhi ahaṅkāra ādi acetanam
translated: These eleven organs are the apprehenders of the eleven objects.🔽There, the internal organ, the principal intellect, egoity, etc. are insentient.

original: tataś ca nūnaṃ cetanena puruṣeṇeśvareṇa vā svabhāveneti /
analyzed: tatas ca nūnam cetanena puruṣeṇa īśvareṇa vā svabhāvena iti
translated: Therefore, it must be by a sentient person, by God, or by nature.

analyzed: atra ucyate guṇa pariṇāma viśeṣāt nānātvam grāhya bhedāt ca
translated: Here it is said: The diversity is due to the specific transformation of the constituents, and also due to the distinction of the objects of cognition.

original: sattvādayas trayo guṇās te yathā pariṇamanti tasmād guṇapariṇāmaviśeṣād imāny ekādaśendriyāṇi nānā /
analyzed: sattva ādayaḥ trayaḥ guṇāḥ te yathā pariṇamanti tasmāt guṇa pariṇāma viśeṣāt imāni ekādaśa indriyāṇi nānā
translated: The three constituents, sattva, etc., transform in that way. Therefore, these eleven organs are diverse due to the specific transformation of the constituents.

analyzed: tad arthāni bhinnāni
translated: They have different objects.

analyzed: śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhāḥ pañcānām
translated: Sound, touch, form, taste, and smell are the objects of the five.

analyzed: vacana ādāna viharaṇa utsarga ānandāḥ pañcānām
translated: Speaking, taking, moving, excreting, and enjoying are the functions of the five.

analyzed: saṅkalpaḥ ca manasaḥ
translated: And determination is the function of the mind.

original: eteṣām eva ekādaśānām indriyāṇi grāhakāṇī bhaviṣyanti /
analyzed: eteṣām eva ekādaśānām indriyāṇi grāhakāṇī bhaviṣyanti
translated: These eleven alone will be the apprehending organs.

original: p / athaitan nānātvaṃ neśvareṇa na buddhyā nāhaṅkāreṇa na pradhānena na puruṣeṇa na svabhāvena kṛtam /
analyzed: atha etat nānātvam na īśvareṇa na buddhyā na ahaṅkāreṇa na pradhānena na puruṣeṇa na svabhāvena kṛtam
translated: Now, this diversity is not made by God, by intellect, by egoity, by primordial matter, by the spirit, or by nature.

analyzed: guṇa pariṇāmena iti
translated: By the transformation of the qualities.

original: yady api uktam acetanānāṃ guṇānāṃ vṛttir ayukteti /
analyzed: yadi api uktam acetanānām guṇānām vṛttiḥ ayuktā iti
translated: Although it has been said that the activity of unconscious qualities is not proper,

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: kasmāt iti ced tat ucyate
translated: If it is asked why, it is said:

analyzed: acetanānām api pravṛttiḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: The activity of unconscious things is also seen.

original: vakṣyati hi 🔽vatsavivṛddhinimittaṃ kṣīrasya yathā pravṛttir ajñasya /
analyzed: vakṣyati hi  vatsa vivṛddhi nimittam kṣīrasya yathā pravṛttiḥ ajñasya
translated: For it will be said:🔽Just as milk flows for the sake of nourishing the calf,

analyzed: puruṣasya vimokṣa artham tathā pravṛttiḥ pradhānasya
translated: so the activity of primordial matter is for the liberation of the conscious self.

analyzed: iti
translated: These are the verses of the Sāṃkhya.

original: tasmād acetanā api guṇā ekādaśendriyabhāvena pariṇamanti /
analyzed: tasmāt acetanāḥ api guṇāḥ ekādaśa indriya bhāvena pariṇamanti
translated: Therefore, even unconscious qualities transform into the state of the eleven sense faculties.

original: atrāha gṛhṇīmas tāvad ekādaśendriyāṇy ahaṅkārād utpannānīti /
analyzed: atra āha gṛhṇīmaḥ tāvat ekādaśa indriyāṇi ahaṅkārāt utpannāni iti
translated: Here it is said: We accept that the eleven sense faculties arise from egoity.

original: eteṣām indriyāṇāṃ yathāsthānanikṣepaḥ kena kṛtaḥ /🔽cakṣur uccaiḥ sanniviṣṭaṃ dūrālokane samarthaṃ bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: eteṣām indriyāṇām yathāsthāna nikṣepaḥ kena kṛtaḥ  cakṣuḥ uccais sanniviṣṭam dūra ālokane samartham bhaviṣyati iti
translated: By whom was the placement of these sense faculties in their respective locations made?🔽The eye was placed high, so that it could be capable of seeing far.

original: śiraḥpradeśe śrotraṃ sanniviṣṭaṃ dūrāc śravaṇasamarthaṃ bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: śiraḥ pradeśe śrotram sanniviṣṭam dūrāt śravaṇa samartham bhaviṣyati iti
translated: The ear was placed in the head region, so that it could be capable of hearing from a distance.

original: tvak śarīrābhyantare bahiś ca sanniviṣṭā nānāsparśagrahaṇasamarthā bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: tvac śarīra abhyantare bahis ca sanniviṣṭā nānā sparśa grahaṇa samarthā bhaviṣyati iti
translated: The skin was placed both inside and outside the body, so that it could be capable of grasping various touches.

analyzed: jihvā antar mukham sanniviṣṭā nānā rasa grahaṇa samarthā bhaviṣyati iti
translated: The tongue, located inside the mouth, will be able to grasp various tastes.

analyzed: evam nāsikā vāc
translated: In the same way, the nose and speech.

original: evam indriyāṇāṃ nikṣepaḥ puruṣeṇa vā kṛta īśvareṇa vā svabhāvena veti /
analyzed: evam indriyāṇām nikṣepaḥ puruṣeṇa vā kṛtaḥ īśvareṇa vā svabhāvena vā iti
translated: Thus, the placement of the senses is done either by the Self, or by God, or by inherent nature.

original: atrocyate iha sāṅkhye puruṣeśvarasvabhāvā na kāraṇam /
analyzed: atra ucyate iha sāṅkhye puruṣa īśvara svabhāvāḥ na kāraṇam
translated: To this it is said: In this Sāṃkhya, the Self, God, and inherent nature are not the cause.

original: kiṃ tarhi asminn ahaṅkāre sthitaiḥ sattvarajastamobhis tribhir guṇair nikṣepaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: kim tarhi asmin ahaṅkāre sthitaiḥ sattva rajaḥ tamobhiḥ tribhiḥ guṇaiḥ nikṣepaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Then what? The placement is made by the three qualities of Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas, which abide in this ego.

original: tasmād brūmaḥ guṇapariṇāmaviśeṣān nānātvaṃ grāhyabhedāc ca /
analyzed: tasmāt brūmaḥ guṇa pariṇāma viśeṣāt nānātvam grāhya bhedāt ca
translated: Therefore, we say: The diversity is due to the specific transformations of the qualities, and also due to the difference in objects of perception.

analyzed: guṇa pariṇāma viśeṣāt ekādaśa indriyāṇām bhedaḥ
translated: The difference of the eleven senses is due to the specific transformations of the qualities.

analyzed: grāhya bhedāt ca
translated: And also due to the difference in objects of perception.

original: grāhyā ekādaśendriyārthās teṣāṃ bhedād apīndriyāṇāṃ bhedaḥ // //
analyzed: grāhyāḥ ekādaśa indriya arthāḥ teṣām bhedāt api indriyāṇām bhedaḥ
translated: The objects of perception are the eleven sense objects. The difference of the senses is also due to their difference.

analyzed: atra āha kā kasya vṛttiḥ ucyate
translated: Here it is asked: What is the function of each? It is said:

analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu pañcānām ālocana matram iṣyate vṛttiḥ
translated: The function of the five is considered to be the apprehension of form and so on.

analyzed: vacana ādāna viharaṇa utsarga ānandāḥ tu pañcānām
translated: But speaking, taking, moving, excreting, and enjoying are the functions of the five.

analyzed: mātra śabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word only means specifically.

analyzed: yathā bhikṣā mātram labhyate na anyaḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: Just as only alms are obtained, not any other specific thing,

analyzed: tathā cakṣuḥ
translated: so is the eye.

analyzed: gata arthe ālocana mātram iti
translated: The meaning is understood: mere cognition.

analyzed: ekaikasya pratīndriyam sva viṣaya grahaṇa sāmarthyam eva
translated: Each has the ability to grasp its own object according to the sense faculty.

original: na hi cakṣuḥ śravaṇasamarthaṃ dānādānasamarthaṃ vā // //
analyzed: na hi cakṣuḥ śravaṇa samartham dāna ādāna samartham vā
translated: For the eye is not capable of hearing, nor is it capable of giving and taking.

original: ata ūrdhvaṃ buddhyahaṅkāramanovṛttiṃ vakṣyāmaḥ / tad ucyate
analyzed: atas ūrdhvam buddhi ahaṅkāra manaḥ vṛttim vakṣyāmaḥ tat ucyate
translated: From here on we will discuss the functions of intellect, ego, and mind. That is said:

original: svālakṣaṇyā vṛttis trayasya saiṣā bhavaty asāmānyā /
analyzed: svālakṣaṇyā vṛttiḥ trayasya sā eṣā bhavati asāmānyā
translated: The function of the three is their own characteristic, which is not common.

analyzed: sāmānya karaṇa vṛttiḥ prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ pañca
translated: The common function of the organs is the five vital airs beginning with prāṇa.

analyzed: svālakṣaṇyā iti
translated: One's own characteristic.

analyzed: buddheḥ adhyavasāyaḥ uktaḥ prāk lakṣaṇam
translated: The definition of intellect was stated earlier as determination.

analyzed: tasyāḥ saḥ eva adhyavasāyaḥ vṛttiḥ
translated: That very determination is its function.

analyzed: evam abhimānaḥ haṅkāra lakṣaṇam
translated: Similarly, the definition of ego is self-assertion.

analyzed: tasya vṛttiḥ api saḥ eva
translated: Its function is also that very [self-assertion].

analyzed: manasaḥ saṅkalpaḥ lakṣaṇam
translated: The definition of mind is conception.

analyzed: tasya api saḥ eva vṛttiḥ
translated: Its function is also that very [conception].

original: yena yena lakṣaṇenāmī lakṣyante teṣāṃ sa eva vṛttiḥ /
analyzed: yena yena lakṣaṇena amī lakṣyante teṣām saḥ eva vṛttiḥ
translated: The function of those [intellect, ego, and mind] is that very [definition] by which they are defined.

original: evaṃ yā buddhīndriyāṇāṃ na sā karmendriyāṇām /
analyzed: evam yā buddhīndriyāṇām na sā karmendriyāṇām
translated: Thus, what is the function of the cognitive organs is not that of the action organs.

original: yā ca karmendriyāṇāṃ na sā buddhīndriyāṇām /
analyzed: yā ca karmendriyāṇām na sā buddhīndriyāṇām
translated: And what is the function of the action organs is not that of the cognitive organs.

analyzed: buddhi ahaṅkāra manasām vṛttiḥ abhihitā
translated: The function of intellect, ego, and mind has been stated.

analyzed: sā api asāmānyā
translated: That too is not common.

analyzed: adhyavasāya abhimāna saṅkalpa lakṣaṇā
translated: It is characterized by determination, conceit, and imagination.

original: saiṣā bhavaty asāmānyā asādhāraṇā evam ukte 'rthāt gamyate sāmānyāpi sādhāraṇāpi vṛttir asti /
analyzed: sā eṣā bhavati asāmānyā asādhāraṇā evam ukte rthāt gamyate sāmānyā api sādhāraṇā api vṛttiḥ asti
translated: When this is said, it is understood that there is also a general and common function.

analyzed: yad apekṣayā asāmānyā iti ucyate
translated: In relation to which it is said to be general.

original: evam indriyāṇām asāmānyā vṛttir ākhyātā kulastrīsaṃsthānīyā /
analyzed: evam indriyāṇām asāmānyā vṛttiḥ ākhyātā kula strī saṃsthānīyā
translated: Thus the uncommon function of the senses is declared to be like that of a courtesan.

analyzed: atas ūrdhvam sāmānyā vṛttiḥ ucyate
translated: From here on, the common function is described.

analyzed: sāmānya karaṇa vṛttiḥ prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ pañca
translated: The common function of the sense organs is the five life-breaths beginning with prana.
The meaning is that it is the common function of the entire internal organ.

original: prāṇādyā vāyavaḥ pañceti prāṇāpānodānasamānavyānāḥ sarveṣām indriyāṇām sāmānyaṃ kurvanti /
analyzed: prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ pañca iti prāṇa apāna udāna samāna vyānāḥ sarveṣām indriyāṇām sāmānyam kurvanti
translated: The five life-breaths beginning with prana are prana, apana, udana, samana, and vyana. They perform the common function of all the senses.

original: sa prāṇo nāma yo mukhanāsāntarago bāhye cāsya viṣaye vṛttiḥ /
analyzed: sa prāṇaḥ nāma yaḥ mukha nāsā antara gaḥ bāhye ca asya viṣaye vṛttiḥ
translated: That which goes in between the mouth and nose, and whose function is external to that, is called prana.

analyzed: prāṇanāt prāṇaḥ eṣaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: Because of the act of breathing, it is called prana.

original: asmin prāṇe yat spandanakarma tat katamena kṛtam ity atrocyate trayodaśavidhena karaṇena kṛtam /
analyzed: asmin prāṇe yat spandana karma tat katamena kṛtam iti atra ucyate trayodaśavidhena karaṇena kṛtam
translated: In this prana, the act of vibration is done by which of the thirteen kinds of organs? This is being stated.

original: yataś caivaṃ tasmāt prāṇakarma sarvasya karaṇagrāmasya vṛttiḥ sāmānyā /
analyzed: yatas ca evam tasmāt prāṇa karma sarvasya karaṇa grāmasya vṛttiḥ sāmānyā
translated: And since this is so, therefore the function of the life force is the common function of the entire group of sense organs.

original: api cātra dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā kasmiṃścid rājagṛhe pañjare śukāḥ prativasanti /
analyzed: api ca atra dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā kasmiṃścid rājagṛhe pañjare śukāḥ prativasanti
translated: Moreover, here is an example: In some king's palace, parrots live in a cage.

analyzed: tebhyaḥ devadattena odanaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: Rice was shown to them by Devadatta.

analyzed: odanam dṛṣṭvā sarve pracalitāḥ
translated: Seeing the rice, all of them moved.

original: tadā pañjarakam api calitam /🔽yat pañjarasya pracalanaṃ karma tat sarveṣām śukānāṃ sāmānyam /
analyzed: tadā pañjarakam api calitam  yat pañjarasya pracalanam karma tat sarveṣām śukānām sāmānyam
translated: Then the cage also moved.🔽The movement of the cage is the common action of all the parrots.

original: tadvat prāṇe yat spandanakarma tat sarveṣām indriyāṇāṃ sāmānyam /
analyzed: tadvat prāṇe yat spandana karma tat sarveṣām indriyāṇām sāmānyam
translated: In the same way, the action of vibration in the life force is the common function of all the sense organs.

analyzed: kim ca anyat apānena utsṛjati
translated: Moreover, one exhales through the apana.

analyzed: itas ca apakramaṇāt apānaḥ iti ucyate
translated: And because of exhalation from here, it is called apana.

original: apānabahulaś ca devadattaḥ sarpaṃ dṛṣṭvā apasarpati eṣo 'pānaḥ /
analyzed: apāna bahulaḥ ca devadattaḥ sarpam dṛṣṭvā apasarpati eṣaḥ u pānaḥ
translated: And Devadatta, who is full of apana, seeing a snake, moves away - this is apana.

original: tasminn apāne yat spandanakarma tat sarveṣām indriyāṇāṃ sāmānyā vṛttiḥ /
analyzed: tasmin apāne yat spandana karma tat sarveṣām indriyāṇām sāmānyā vṛttiḥ
translated: The action of vibration in that apana is the common function of all the sense organs.

analyzed: ārohaṇāt artha utkarṣe udānaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: Because of ascending, it is called udana in the case of the rise of objects.

analyzed: nābhi pradeśāt utthitam gacchati
translated: It arises from the region of the navel and goes up.

analyzed: udāna vṛttiḥ ca devadattaḥ ānanda utkarṣam mṛgayati
translated: And Devadatta, whose function is udana, seeks the rise of bliss.

original: aham āḍhyo 'smād āḍhyataraḥ kathaṃ syām ity eṣa udānaḥ /
analyzed: aham āḍhyaḥ smāt āḍhyataraḥ katham syām iti eṣaḥ udānaḥ
translated: The upward-moving breath is the effort to think, How can I be richer than this rich person?

original: asminn udāne yat spandanakarma tat sāmānyā vṛttiḥ sarvendriyāṇām /
analyzed: asmin udāne yat spandana karma tat sāmānyā vṛttiḥ sarva indriyāṇām
translated: The function common to all the senses is the movement that occurs in this upward-moving breath.

original: kiñ cānyat hṛdyavasthānaṃ sahabhāvaś ca tena samānaḥ /
analyzed: kim ca anyat hṛdi avasthānam sahabhāvaḥ ca tena samānaḥ
translated: Moreover, it is located in the heart and is associated with it.

original: yo vāyur hṛddeśe vartate sa samānaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ vāyuḥ hṛd deśe vartate sa samānaḥ
translated: The breath that moves in the region of the heart is the equalizing breath.

original: tadbahulaś ca ekākī na ramata eṣa samānaḥ /
analyzed: tad bahulaḥ ca ekākī na ramate eṣa samānaḥ
translated: And one who is full of that equalizing breath does not enjoy being alone.

original: tasmin yat spandanakarma tat sarvendriyāṇāṃ sāmānyavṛttiḥ /
analyzed: tasmin yat spandana karma tat sarva indriyāṇām sāmānya vṛttiḥ
translated: The function of movement in that equalizing breath is the common function of all the senses.

analyzed: kim ca anyat śarīra vyāpi tayā vyānaḥ
translated: Moreover, the pervading breath is due to pervading the body.

original: ānakhād ākeśāntaṃ śarīraṃ vyāpya anati calatīti vyānaḥ /
analyzed: ā nakhāt ā keśāntam śarīram vyāpya anati calati iti vyānaḥ
translated: The pervading breath moves pervading the body from the nails to the tips of the hair without moving too much.

original: vyānabahulo devadattaś ca atyantam anyena vinā ramate /
analyzed: vyāna bahulaḥ devadattaḥ ca atyantam anyena vinā ramate
translated: And Devadatta, who is full of the pervading breath, enjoys being without another person very much.

original: p / tasmin vyāne yat spandanakarma tat sarveṣām indriyāṇāṃ sāmānyavṛttiḥ /
analyzed: tasmin vyāne yat spandana karma tat sarveṣām indriyāṇām sāmānya vṛttiḥ
translated: The function of movement in that pervading breath is the common function of all the senses.

original: tad evaṃ sāmānyakāraṇavṛttiḥ prāṇādyā vāyavo vyākhyātāḥ // //
analyzed: tat evam sāmānya kāraṇa vṛttiḥ prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: Thus, the breaths beginning with the life breath, which are the common causes of functions, have been explained.

analyzed: vṛttim vyākhyāsyāmaḥ tat ucyate
translated: Now we will explain the functions. That is being stated:

original: yugapac catuṣṭayasya hi vṛttiḥ kramaśaś ca tasya nirdiṣṭā /
analyzed: yugapad catuṣṭayasya hi vṛttiḥ kramaśas ca tasya nirdiṣṭā
translated: The function of the four is simultaneous, and that is indicated to be sequential.

original: dṛṣṭe tathāpy adṛṣṭe trayasya tatpūrvikā vṛttiḥ // //
analyzed: dṛṣṭe tathā api adṛṣṭe trayasya tad pūrvikā vṛttiḥ
translated: Even when seen, when unseen, the function of the three is preceded by that.

original: buddhir ahaṅkāro manaś cakṣur ity etāni catvāri yugapad rūpaṃ paśyanti /
analyzed: buddhiḥ ahaṅkāraḥ manaḥ cakṣuḥ iti etāni catvāri yugapad rūpam paśyanti
translated: Intellect, ego, mind, and eye - these four simultaneously see form.

analyzed: ayam sthāṇuḥ yam puruṣaḥ iti
translated: This is a post, this is a man.

original: evaṃ śabdaṃ sparśaṃ rasaṃ gandhaṃ catvāri yugapad gṛhṇanti /
analyzed: evam śabdam sparśam rasam gandham catvāri yugapad gṛhṇanti
translated: In the same way, they simultaneously grasp sound, touch, taste, and smell.

analyzed: evam eṣā yugapad catuṣṭayasya vṛttiḥ
translated: Thus, the function of the four is simultaneous.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: What else?

original: kramaśaś ca tasya nirdiṣṭā buddhyahaṅkāramanaścakṣuścatuṣṭayasya kramaśo vṛttir bhavati /
analyzed: kramaśas ca tasya nirdiṣṭā buddhi ahaṅkāra manaḥ cakṣuḥ catuṣṭayasya kramaśas vṛttiḥ bhavati
translated: And the function of that four - intellect, ego, mind, and eye - is sequential.

original: dvāridvāravibhāgopadeśād hrasvakālatvād vibhāgo na śakyate vaktuṃ tato yugapad ity ucyate /
analyzed: dvāri dvāra vibhāga upadeśāt hrasva kāla tvāt vibhāgaḥ na śakyate vaktum tatas yugapad iti ucyate
translated: The division into door and non-door cannot be stated due to the short duration, therefore it is said to be simultaneous.

analyzed: yathā bāla patra śatam sūci agreṇa viddham iti
translated: Just as it is said a hundred tender leaves are pierced by the tip of a needle.

analyzed: tat yathā
translated: It is like this.

original: devadattaḥ panthānaṃ gacchan sthāṇuṃ paśyati tatra tasya saṃśayo bhavati kim ayaṃ sthāṇur uta puruṣa iti /
analyzed: devadattaḥ panthānam gacchan sthāṇum paśyati tatra tasya saṃśayaḥ bhavati kim ayam sthāṇuḥ uta puruṣaḥ iti
translated: Devadatta, walking on the path, sees a post. There, doubt arises in him: Is this a post or a man?

original: tatra sthāṇurūpaṃ paśyati śakuniṃ ca tatrasthaṃ tato 'sya buddhir bhavati sthāṇur ayam iti /
analyzed: tatra sthāṇu rūpam paśyati śakunim ca tatrastham tatas sya buddhiḥ bhavati sthāṇuḥ ayam iti
translated: There, he sees the form of a post and a bird perched on it. Then he has the idea, This is a post.

original: ākuñcanaprasāraṇe karoti tato 'pi puruṣo 'yam iti pratītiḥ /
analyzed: ākuñcana prasāraṇe karoti puruṣaḥ yam iti pratītiḥ
translated: When it contracts and expands, he also has the notion, This is a man.

original: evaṃ buddhyahaṅkāramanaścakṣuṣāṃ kramaśo vṛttir dṛṣṭā cakṣū rūpaṃ paśyati /
analyzed: evam buddhi ahaṅkāra manaḥ cakṣuṣām kramaśas vṛttiḥ dṛṣṭā cakṣuḥ rūpam paśyati
translated: Thus, the function of the intellect, ego, mind, and eyes is seen in order. The eye sees form.

analyzed: manaḥ saṅkalpayati
translated: The mind conceives.

analyzed: ahaṅkāraḥ bhimānayati
translated: The ego is proud.

analyzed: buddhiḥ adhyavasyati
translated: The intellect determines.

analyzed: evam rasanā ādiṣu api draṣṭavyam
translated: The same should be seen for the tongue and so on.

analyzed: kim ca anyat dṛṣṭe tathā api adṛṣṭe
translated: Moreover, even when seen, it is unseen.

analyzed: trayasya tad pūrvikā vṛttiḥ
translated: The function of the three is preceded by that.

analyzed: tad śabdena samanantara uktāni buddhīndriyāṇi bhavanti
translated: The word that refers to the intellect, ego, and mind, which were mentioned immediately before.

analyzed: rūpe cakṣuḥ pūrvikā
translated: And in form, it is preceded by the eye.

analyzed: śabde śrotra pūrvikā  sparśe tvac pūrvikā
translated: In sound, it is preceded by the ear.🔽In touch, it is preceded by the skin.

analyzed: rase jihvā pūrvikā
translated: In taste, it is preceded by the tongue.

analyzed: gandhe ghrāṇa pūrvikā buddhi ahaṅkāra manasām vṛttiḥ iti
translated: In smell, the function of the intellect, ego, and mind is preceded by the nose.

original: atrāha acetanānīndriyāṇi buddhyahaṅkārau manaś ceti kena hetunā svāṃ svāṃ vṛttiṃ pratipadyante ity atrāha
analyzed: atra āha acetanāni indriyāṇi buddhi ahaṅkārau manaḥ ca iti kena hetunā svām svām vṛttim pratipadyante iti atra āha
translated: Here he says: The senses are insentient, and the intellect, ego, and mind - by what reason do they engage in their own functions? To this he says:

analyzed: svām svām pratipadyante paraspara ākūta hetukām vṛttim
translated: They attain their own functions, which are caused by the mutual intentions.

original: puruṣārtha eva hetur na kenacit kāryate karaṇam // //
analyzed: puruṣa arthaḥ eva hetuḥ na kenacid kāryate karaṇam
translated: The purpose of the Spirit is the only cause. No instrument is made by anyone.

analyzed: svām svām iti vīpsām icchanti
translated: They attain their own, their own, they desire to continue.

original: iti trayodaśavidhasya karaṇasya grahaṇaṃ kṛtaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: iti trayodaśavidhasya karaṇasya grahaṇam kṛtam bhavati
translated: Thus the inclusion of the thirteen kinds of instruments is made.

analyzed: pratipadyante gṛhṇanti iti arthaāḥ
translated: They attain, they grasp, is the meaning.

analyzed: kim ca anyat paraspara ākūta hetukām vṛttim
translated: And what else? The function which is caused by the mutual intentions.

analyzed: buddheḥ ākūtam jñātvā ahaṅkāraḥ bhimānayati
translated: Having known the intention of the intellect, the ego abides in pride.

analyzed: manaḥ saṅkalpayati
translated: The mind resolves.

analyzed: indriyāṇi svām svām vṛttim pratipadyante
translated: The senses attain their own functions.

original: ākūtaṃ nāmābhiprāyaḥ /🔽yathā kila caurasenā grāmaṃ hantuṃ gacchati tatra caurasenāpatinā saṅketaḥp /
analyzed: ākūtam nāma abhiprāyaḥ  yathā kila caura senā grāmam hantum gacchati tatra caura senāpatinā
translated: Intention is a purpose.

original: kṛto 'sti yadāhaṃ hā heti bravīmi tadā sarvaiḥ samavāyena praveṣṭavyam /
analyzed: sti yadā aham hā hā iti bravīmi tadā sarvaiḥ samavāyena praveṣṭavyam
translated: For example, a band of thieves goes to a village to kill it, and an agreement is made by the leader of the thieves there, that when I say 'ha he', then all of you should enter together.

original: yadā punar aham ahā heti bravīmi tadā nirgantavyam /
analyzed: yadā punar aham ahā hā iti bravīmi tadā nirgantavyam
translated: But when I say 'a ha he', then you should come out.

original: etāṃ caurasenāpater ājñām ākūtaṃ jñātvā caurāḥ praviśanti nirgacchanti ca /
analyzed: etām caura senāpateḥ ājñām ākūtam jñātvā caurāḥ praviśanti nirgacchanti ca
translated: Having known the intention, the purpose of the leader of the thieves, the thieves enter and come out.

analyzed: tathā iha caura senāpati sthānīyā buddhiḥ caura sthānīyāni indriyāṇi
translated: Similarly, here, intellect is like the commander of a thief army, and the senses are like the thieves.

original: kiṃ svārthaṃ viṣayaṃ pratipadyante āhosvit parārtham ity atrocyate /
analyzed: kim sva artham viṣayam pratipadyante āhosvit para artham iti atra ucyate
translated: To what purpose do they engage with objects, for their own sake or for someone else's? Here it is said:

analyzed: para artham gamyate
translated: They engage for someone else's sake.

original: yasmād āha puruṣārtha eva hetuḥ puruṣārthaḥ kartavya eva iti guṇānāṃ pravṛttiḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt āha puruṣa arthaḥ eva hetuḥ puruṣa arthaḥ kartavyaḥ eva iti guṇānām pravṛttiḥ
translated: Because it is said that the purpose of the qualities is only for the sake of the self, that the self's purpose should be accomplished.

original: tasmād etat trayodaśavidhaṃ karaṇaṃ puruṣārthaḥ pravartayati /
analyzed: tasmāt etat trayodaśavidham karaṇam puruṣa arthaḥ pravartayati
translated: Therefore, this thirteenfold instrument causes the self's purpose to be accomplished.

original: yad apy uktam acetanāni karaṇāni kathaṃ pravartanta iti /
analyzed: yat api uktam acetanāni karaṇāni katham pravartante iti
translated: As for what was said, how do the insentient instruments operate?

original: atra brūmaḥ na kenacit kāryate karaṇam /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ na kenacid kāryate karaṇam
translated: Here we say: The instrument is not caused by anything.

analyzed: na īśvareṇa na api puruṣeṇa
translated: Not by God, nor by the self.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ nāma kaścid padārthaḥ na asti
translated: There is no such thing as a substance called nature.

original: yasmāt svayam eva ca trayodaśavidhaṃ karaṇaṃ sve sve viṣaye pravartata iti // //
analyzed: yasmāt svayam eva ca trayodaśavidham karaṇam sve sve viṣaye pravartate iti
translated: Because the thirteenfold instrument itself operates in its own domain.

original: atrāha uktaṃ ca bhagavatā na kenacit kāryate karaṇam iti /
analyzed: atra āha uktam ca bhagavatā na kenacid kāryate karaṇam iti
translated: Here it is said: And it was said by the Blessed One that the instrument is not caused by anything.

analyzed: tat katividham karaṇam iti atra ucyate
translated: How many kinds of instruments are there? Here it is said:

analyzed: karaṇam trayodaśavidham tad āharaṇa dhāraṇa prakāśa karam
translated: The instrument is of thirteen kinds, causing the bringing, holding, and illumination.

original: kāryaṃ ca tasya daśadhāhāryaṃ dhāryaṃ prakāśyaṃ ca // //
analyzed: kāryam ca tasya daśadhā āhāryam dhāryam prakāśyam ca
translated: And its function is to be grasped, to be sustained, and to be manifested in ten ways.

original: yad atra karaṇam ity uktaṃ tat trayodaśavidham iti boddhyam /
analyzed: yat atra karaṇam iti uktam tat trayodaśavidham iti boddhyam
translated: It should be understood that what is called the instrument here is of thirteen kinds.

analyzed: pañca karmendriyāṇi
translated: There are five organs of action,

analyzed: pañca buddhīndriyāṇi
translated: five organs of knowledge,

original: buddhyahaṅkārau mana iti etat trayodaśavidhaṃ karaṇam iti /
analyzed: buddhi ahaṅkārau manaḥ iti etat trayodaśavidham karaṇam iti
translated: and the intellect, ego, and mind - this is the thirteenfold instrument.

original: atrāha āhārakaṃ dhārakaṃ prakāśakaṃ ca tad iti /
analyzed: atra āha āhārakam dhārakam prakāśakam ca tat iti
translated: Here it is said: it is that which grasps, sustains, and manifests.

analyzed: tatra āhārakam indriya lakṣaṇam
translated: Among them, the characteristic of the organ is that which grasps.

analyzed: dhārakam abhimāna lakṣaṇam
translated: The characteristic of ego is that which sustains.

analyzed: prakāśakam buddhi lakṣaṇam
translated: The characteristic of the intellect is that which manifests.

original: atrāha kiṃ tad asti yasyāharaṇaṃ dhāraṇaṃ prakāśanaṃ ca kriyate /
analyzed: atra āha kim tat asti yasya āharaṇam dhāraṇam prakāśanam ca kriyate
translated: Here it is asked: is there anything that is grasped, sustained, and manifested?

original: atrocyate kāryaṃ ca tasya daśadhāhāryaṃ dhāryaṃ prakāśyaṃ ca /
analyzed: atrā ucyate kāryam ca tasya daśadhā āhāryam dhāryam prakāśyam ca
translated: Here it is said: and its function is to be grasped, to be sustained, and to be manifested in ten ways.

analyzed: kāryam iti śabda sparśa rasa rūpa gandhāḥ pañca
translated: The function is the five objects: sound, touch, taste, form, and smell.

analyzed: vacana ādāna viharaṇa utsarga ānandāḥ pañca
translated: The five actions are speaking, taking, moving, excreting, and enjoying.

original: ete daśa viṣayāḥ kāryam ity ucyate /
analyzed: ete daśa viṣayāḥ kāryam iti ucyate
translated: These ten objects are called the function.

original: taṃ daśavidhaṃ viṣayaṃ buddhīndriyaiḥ prakāśitam arthaṃ karmendriyāṇy āharanti dhārayanti ca /
analyzed: tam daśavidham viṣayam buddhīndriyaiḥ prakāśitam artham karmendriyāṇi āharanti dhārayanti ca
translated: The organs of action grasp and sustain the object that is manifested by the organs of knowledge in these ten ways.

original: tad yathā tamasi sthitaṃ pradīpena prakāśitaṃ ghaṭaṃ hasta ādatte dhārayati ca /
analyzed: tat yathā tamasi sthitam pradīpena prakāśitam ghaṭam haste ādatte dhārayati ca
translated: Just as one takes up and holds a pot that is illuminated by a lamp in the darkness.

original: tad evaṃ yathā ghaṭaṃ tathā śeṣāṇy api // //🔽antaḥkaraṇaṃ trividhaṃ daśadhā bāhyaṃ trayasya viṣayākhyam /
analyzed: tat evam yathā ghaṭam tathā śeṣāṇi api  antaḥkaraṇam trividham daśadhā bāhyam trayasya viṣaya ākhyam
translated: Just as with the pot, so with the rest.🔽The internal organ is threefold, the external is tenfold, and is called the object of the three.

analyzed: sāmprata kālam bāhyam tri kālam ābhyantaram karaṇam
translated: The external is of the present time, the internal organ is of the three times.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇam trividham iti buddhi ahaṅkāra manasām grahaṇam
translated: The internal organ is threefold - this refers to intellect, ego, and mind.

analyzed: etat trividham antaḥkaraṇa saṃjñitam
translated: This threefold one is designated as the internal organ.

analyzed: daśadhā bāhyam buddhi karma indriya bhedāt
translated: The external is tenfold, due to the division of the organs of knowledge and action.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And what else?

original: trayasya viṣayākhyaṃ buddhyahaṅkāramanasāṃ trayāṇām antaḥkaraṇānāṃ bāhyaṃ daśavidhaṃp /
analyzed: trayasya viṣaya ākhyam buddhi ahaṅkāra manasām trayāṇām antaḥkaraṇānām bāhyam
translated: The external of the three, which is called the object, is tenfold. The external organ of the three - intellect, ego, and mind - is tenfold.

analyzed: karaṇam viṣaya ākhyam viṣaya
translated: It is called the object, the object.

analyzed: upabhogyam iti
translated: It is to be enjoyed.

original: ābhyantaraṃ trikaṃ svāmibhūtaṃ bāhyaṃ daśavidhaṃ bhṛtyabhūtam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: ābhyantaram trikam svāmi bhūtam bāhyam daśavidham bhṛtya bhūtam iti arthaḥ
translated: The internal triad is the lord, the external tenfold one is the servant - this is the meaning.

analyzed: kim ca anyat sāmprata kālam bāhyam
translated: And what else? The external is of the present time.

original: yad etad bāhyaṃ daśavidhaṃ karaṇam uktaṃ tat sāmpratakālaṃ vartamānaviṣayagrāhakaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yat etat bāhyam daśavidham karaṇam uktam tat sāmprata kālam vartamāna viṣaya grāhakam bhavati
translated: The external organs, which are of ten kinds, are said to be present, i.e., functioning in the present time, and to grasp objects of the present time.

analyzed: śrotra tvac cakṣuḥ jihvā ghrāṇāni vartamānāni eva śabda ādīni gṛhṇanti
translated: The ear, skin, eye, tongue and nose grasp only present sounds, etc.

analyzed: na atītāni na ca bhāvīni
translated: Not past, nor future.

original: evaṃ vākpāṇipādapāyūpasthāni vartamāneṣu vacanādeyabhūmimalotsargānandeṣu pravartante nātītābhaviṣyatoḥ /
analyzed: evam vāc pāṇi pāda pāyu upasthāni vartamāneṣu vacana ādeya bhūmi mala utsarga ānandeṣu pravartante na atīta abhaviṣyatoḥ
translated: Similarly, the organs of speech, hands, feet, anus and genitals function in relation to speaking, grasping, walking, excretion and pleasure, which are present, not past or future.

original: kiñ cānyat trikālam ābhyantaraṃ mano'haṅkārabuddhirūpaṃ karaṇaṃ pravartate /
analyzed: kim ca anyat tri kālam ābhyantaram manaḥ haṅkāra buddhi rūpam karaṇam pravartate
translated: Moreover, the internal organs of mind, ego and intellect function in all three times.

original: buddhir vartamānaṃ ghaṭaṃ buddhyate atītaṃ bhaviṣyantaṃ ca smarati /
analyzed: buddhiḥ vartamānam ghaṭam buddhyate atītam bhaviṣyantam ca smarati
translated: The intellect cognizes the present pot, and remembers the past and the future.

original: tad yathā yudhiṣṭhirabhīmasenāv āstām atītaviṣayagrāhiṇī buddhiḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā yudhiṣṭhira bhīmasenau āstām atīta viṣaya grāhiṇī buddhiḥ
translated: For example, the intellect grasping past objects was present in Yudhishthira and Bhimasena.

analyzed: kalkī bhaviṣyati bhāvi vastu grāhiṇī
translated: The intellect grasping future objects will be present in Kalki.

analyzed: evam ahaṅkāraḥ trikālavān
translated: Similarly, the ego also exists in all three times.

analyzed: yathā aham asmin gṛhe svāmī āsam
translated: As I was the master of this house,

analyzed: bhaviṣyāmi ca iti
translated: and I will be again.

original: evaṃ mano 'py atītaṃ saṅkalpayati vartamānaṃ bhāvi ca /
analyzed: evam manaḥ pi atītam saṅkalpayati vartamānam bhāvi ca
translated: Similarly, the mind also conceives the past, present and future.

original: yata evaṃ tasmād ucyate trikālam ābhyantaraṃ karaṇam iti // //
analyzed: yatas evam tasmāt ucyate tri kālam ābhyantaram karaṇam iti
translated: Since this is so, therefore it is said that the internal organ operates in all three times.

original: atrāha kāni indriyāṇi saviśeṣaṃ viṣayaṃ gṛhṇanti /
analyzed: atra āha kāni indriyāṇi sa viśeṣam viṣayam gṛhṇanti
translated: Here it is asked: Which senses grasp objects with specific qualities?

analyzed: kāni nirviśeṣam
translated: Which grasp objects without specific qualities? To this it is said:

analyzed: buddhīndriyāṇi teṣām pañca viśeṣa aviśeṣa viṣayāṇi
translated: Among them, the five sense organs have objects with specific and non-specific qualities.

original: vāg bhavati śabdaviṣayā śeṣāny api pañcaviṣayāṇi // //
analyzed: vāc bhavati śabda viṣayā śeṣāni api pañca viṣayāṇi
translated: Speech has sound as its object, and the remaining five also have five objects.

original: teṣām karaṇānāṃ madhye yeṣām ayam adhikāro vartate teṣāṃ yāni buddhīndriyāṇi śrotratvakcakṣurjihvāghrāṇāni pañca tāni saviśeṣaṃ gṛhṇanti aviśeṣam
analyzed: teṣām karaṇānām madhye yeṣām ayam adhikāraḥ vartate teṣām yāni buddhīndriyāṇi śrotra tvac cakṣuḥ jihvā ghrāṇāni pañca tāni sa viśeṣam gṛhṇanti aviśeṣam
translated: Among those organs, to which this discussion applies, the five sense organs of hearing, touch, sight, taste, and smell grasp objects with specific qualities.

analyzed: api viṣayam gṛhṇanti
translated: They also grasp objects without specific qualities.

original: atrāha kasya saviśeṣaṃ viṣayaṃ gṛhṇanti kasya nirviśeṣam iti /
analyzed: atra āha kasya sa viśeṣam viṣayam gṛhṇanti kasya nirviśeṣam iti
translated: Here it is asked: Whose objects do they grasp with specific qualities? Whose without specific qualities?

original: atrocyate śabdasparśarasarūpagandhāḥ pajña devānāṃ tanmātrasaṃjñitā nirviśeṣāḥ kevalasukhalakṣaṇatvāt /
analyzed: atra ucyate śabda sparśa rasa rūpa gandhāḥ devānām tanmātra saṃjñitāḥ nirviśeṣāḥ kevala sukha lakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: To this it is said: Sound, touch, taste, form, and smell are the gods' tanmatras, known as the subtle elements, without specific qualities, because they are characterized solely by pleasure.

original: yasmāt tatra duḥkhamohau na stas tasmān nirviśeṣās te iti /
analyzed: yasmāt tatra duḥkha mohau na staḥ tasmāt nirviśeṣāḥ te iti
translated: Since neither pain nor delusion exist there, therefore they are without specific qualities.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is because:

original: viśiṣyante śāntaghoramūḍhatvādineti viśeṣās taiḥ saha saviśeṣāḥ /
analyzed: viśiṣyante śānta ghora mūḍha tva ādinā iti viśeṣāḥ taiḥ saha sa viśeṣāḥ
translated: They are distinguished by being peaceful, fierce, deluded, etc., so they are with distinctions.

analyzed: kevalāḥ nirviśeṣāḥ iti tātparyam
translated: The meaning is that they are solely without distinctions.

original: evaṃ śabdādayo manuṣyāṇāṃ saviśeṣāḥ sukhaduḥkhamohayuktā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: evam śabda ādayaḥ manuṣyāṇām sa viśeṣāḥ sukha duḥkha moha yuktāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, sound and so on are with distinctions for humans, meaning they are associated with pleasure, pain, and delusion.

original: devānāṃ tu buddhīndriyāṇi nirviśeṣaṃ sukhātmakaṃ prakāśayanti /
analyzed: devānām tu buddhīndriyāṇi nirviśeṣam sukha ātmakam prakāśayanti
translated: But for gods, the cognitive senses solely manifest the nature of pleasure.

analyzed: uktāni buddhīndriyāṇi devānām mānuṣāṇām ca
translated: The cognitive senses of gods and humans have been explained.

analyzed: karmendriyāṇi vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will now discuss the action senses.

original: vāg bhavati śabdaviṣayā śeṣāny api pañca viṣayāṇi /
analyzed: vāc bhavati śabda viṣayā śeṣāni api pañca viṣayāṇi
translated: Speech is for the purpose of sound. The remaining five are also for the purpose of the five objects.

original: tatra devānāṃ vāk pādaṃ pādārdhaṃ ślokam uccārayati /
analyzed: tatra devānām vāc pādam pāda ardham ślokam uccārayati
translated: Among them, the speech of gods utters a verse in a quarter or half a quarter.

analyzed: asmākam api tathā eva
translated: The same is true for us.

original: ato devānām asmākaṃ ca vāgindriyaṃ tulyam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: atas devānām asmākam ca vāc indriyam tulyam iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that the speech sense of gods and us is equal.

original: kiṃ cānyat śeṣāṇy api pañca viṣayāṇi iti /
analyzed: kim ca anyat śeṣāṇi api pañca viṣayāṇi iti
translated: What else? The remaining five are also for the purpose of the five objects.

analyzed: caturṇām ekaikam pañca viṣayam
translated: Among those four, each has five objects.

analyzed: pāṇiḥ tāvat śabda sparśa rasa rūpa gandha yuktaḥ
translated: The hand is endowed with sound, touch, taste, form, and smell.

original: evaṃ pañcalakṣaṇam eva pāṇīndriyaṃ sannikṛṣṭaṃ pañcalakṣaṇaṃ ghaṭaṃ gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: evam pañca lakṣaṇam eva pāṇi indriyam sannikṛṣṭam pañca lakṣaṇam ghaṭam gṛhṇāti
translated: Thus, the hand sense, which has five characteristics, grasps an object with five characteristics when it is in contact with it.

original: yasmāt pañcalakṣaṇaṃ hastaṃ hastendriyaṃ ca🔽evaṃ śabdādipañcalakṣaṇaḥ pādaḥ pañcātmikāyām eva bhuvi viharati /
analyzed: yasmāt pañca lakṣaṇam hastam hasta indriyam ca  evam śabda ādi pañca lakṣaṇaḥ pādaḥ pañca ātmikāyām eva bhuvi viharati
translated: Because the hand with five characteristics is the hand faculty,🔽and similarly, the foot with five characteristics moves only on the five-natured earth.

original: evaṃ pañcalakṣaṇe pāyūpasthe api pañcalakṣaṇāv utsargānandau kurutaḥ /
analyzed: evam pañca lakṣaṇe pāyu upasthe api pañca lakṣaṇau utsarga ānandau kurutaḥ
translated: Similarly, the anus and genitals with five characteristics produce the five-natured discharge and pleasure.

original: tasmāt yuktam abhihitam śeṣāṇy api pañca viṣayāṇi iti // //
analyzed: tasmāt yuktam abhihitam śeṣāṇi api pañca viṣayāṇi iti
translated: Therefore, it is rightly said that the remaining five are objects.

analyzed: idānīm buddhi viṣaya khyāpanāya idam ucyate
translated: Now, this is said to explain the objects of the intellect:

original: sāntaḥkaraṇā buddhiḥ sarvaṃ viṣayam avagāhate yasmāt /
analyzed: sa antaḥkaraṇā buddhiḥ sarvam viṣayam avagāhate yasmāt
translated: Since the intellect along with the internal organ penetrates all objects,

original: tasmāt trividhaṃ karaṇaṃ dvāri dvārāṇi śeṣāṇi // //
analyzed: tasmāt trividham karaṇam dvāri dvārāṇi śeṣāṇi
translated: therefore the instrument is threefold, the others are doors.

original: sāntaḥkaraṇā antaḥkaraṇe ahaṃmanasī tābhyāṃ saha vartate yā buddhiḥ sā tathoktā /
analyzed: sa antaḥkaraṇā antaḥkaraṇe aham manasī tābhyām saha vartate yā buddhiḥ sā tathā uktā
translated: The intellect along with the internal organ, which exists together with the internal organ consisting of the ego and mind, is called that.

original: sā buddhiḥ sarvaṃ viṣayaṃ niravaśeṣaṃ triṣv api kāleṣu yasmād avagāhate vyāpnoti
analyzed: sā buddhiḥ sarvam viṣayam niravaśeṣam triṣu api kāleṣu yasmāt avagāhate vyāpnoti
translated: Since that intellect penetrates, pervades, and grasps all objects without exception in all three times,

original: gṛhṇāti śabdādyaṃ pañcavidhaṃ tasmād eva tanmanobuddhyahaṅkāralakṣaṇaṃ trividham🔽eva karaṇaṃ sādhanaṃ /
analyzed: gṛhṇāti śabda ādyam pañcavidham tasmāt eva tat manaḥ buddhi ahaṅkāra lakṣaṇam trividham  eva karaṇam sādhanam
translated: therefore that instrument consisting of the three, namely the mind, intellect, and ego, which has five objects such as sound, is threefold.🔽It is an instrument, because it is made by that.

analyzed: kriyate nena iti kṛtvā
translated: It is so called because it is made by that.

original: śeṣāṇi punaḥ dvāri bāhye yāni buddhikarmendriyatayā pratītāni śrotravākprabhṛtīni
analyzed: śeṣāṇi punar dvāri bāhye yāni buddhi karmendriya tayā pratītāni śrotra vāc prabhṛtīni
translated: The remaining ones, however, which are known as the organs of knowledge and action, such as the ear, speech, etc., are located outside the door.

original: daśa tāni tasyā eva mano'haṅkārayuktāyā buddher viṣayagrahaṇāya dvārāṇi pratīkāny
analyzed: daśa tāni tasyāḥ eva manaḥ haṅkāra yuktāyāḥ buddheḥ viṣaya grahaṇāya dvārāṇi pratīkāni
translated: Those ten are mere symbols for that very intellect, which is endowed with the mind and ego, to grasp objects.

analyzed: eva na tu karaṇatayā sa anvayāni
translated: They are not endowed with the function of organs.

original: tathā etair daśabhir dvāraiḥ sāntaḥkaraṇā buddhir eva viṣayān gṛhṇātīti trividham eva karaṇam ity arthaḥ // //
analyzed: tathā etaiḥ daśabhiḥ dvāraiḥ sa antaḥkaraṇā buddhiḥ eva viṣayān gṛhṇāti iti trividham eva karaṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, it is the intellect itself, along with the internal organs, that grasps objects through those ten doors. The meaning is that there are only three organs.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And furthermore,

analyzed: ete pradīpa kalpāḥ paraspara vilakṣaṇāḥ guṇa viśeṣāḥ
translated: These specific qualities, which are like lamps and mutually distinct,

analyzed: kṛtsnam puruṣasya artham prakāśya buddhau prayacchanti
translated: Illuminate the entire purpose of the Purusha and deliver it to the intellect.

original: ete iti buddhikarmāntaḥkaraṇabhedās trayodeśa pradīpakalpāḥ pradīpatulyāḥ /
analyzed: ete iti buddhi karma antaḥkaraṇa bhedāḥ pradīpa kalpāḥ pradīpa tulyāḥ
translated: The meaning of these is the three divisions of intellect, organs of action, and internal organs, which are like lamps.

analyzed: kim ca anyat  paraspara vilakṣaṇāḥ
translated: And furthermore,🔽They are mutually distinct.

analyzed: bhinna lakṣaṇāḥ visadṛśāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they have different characteristics and are dissimilar.

analyzed: śrotram hi śabdam gṛhṇāti
translated: For the ear grasps sound,

analyzed: na sparśa ādīn
translated: Not touch and so on.

analyzed: evam itaratra
translated: The same applies to the others.

original: vāg vakty eva na gṛhṇāti gacchati viharaty ānandati /
analyzed: vāc vakti eva na gṛhṇāti gacchati viharati ānandati
translated: Speech speaks, it does not grasp. It goes, it enjoys, it delights.

analyzed: evam pāṇi ādiṣu
translated: The same applies to the hands and so on.

analyzed: manaḥ saṅkalpayati na ahaṅkurute
translated: The mind conceives, it does not make the I-notion.

analyzed: ahaṅkāraḥ ca abhimanute na saṅkalpayati
translated: The I-notion approves, it does not conceive.

original: evaṃ dvādaśāpi svaṃ svam arthaṃ puruṣabhogyatayā prakāśya buddhau prayacchanti nikṣipanti /
analyzed: evam dvādaśa api svam svam artham puruṣa bhogya tayā prakāśya buddhau prayacchanti nikṣipanti
translated: Thus, all twelve reveal their own objects as to be enjoyed by the Spirit and hand them over to the Buddhi, they deposit them.

original: tad buddhisthaṃ viṣayaṃ sukhaduḥkhādyaṃ puruṣa upalabhate // //
analyzed: tat buddhi stham viṣayam sukha duḥkha ādyam puruṣaḥ upalabhate
translated: The Spirit experiences that object which is in the Buddhi, such as pleasure, pain, etc.

analyzed: kim ca anyat
translated: And further,

original: sarvaṃ pratyupabhogaṃ yasmāt puruṣasya sādhayati buddhiḥ /
analyzed: sarvam pratyupabhogam yasmāt puruṣasya sādhayati buddhiḥ
translated: because the Buddhi accomplishes all objects of enjoyment for the Spirit,

original: saiva ca viśinaṣṭi tataḥ pradhānapuruṣāntaraṃ sūkṣmam // //
analyzed: sā eva ca viśinaṣṭi tatas pradhāna puruṣa antaram sūkṣmam
translated: and it alone distinguishes the subtle difference between the Prakriti and the Spirit.

original: nirviśeṣaṃ triṣv api kāleṣu yo yo viṣayaṃ prati upabhogo devatiryagyoniṣu taṃ taṃ puruṣasya yasmād hetor buddhir eva sādhayati niṣpādayati
analyzed: nirviśeṣam triṣu api kāleṣu yaḥ yaḥ viṣayam prati upabhogaḥ deva tiryagyoniṣu tam tam puruṣasya yasmāt hetoḥ buddhiḥ eva sādhayati niṣpādayati
translated: The Spirit's enjoyment of each object in the three times is accomplished by the Buddhi alone, because of this reason.

analyzed: rāja amātya vat
translated: Like a king and his minister.

original: yathā sarveṣāṃ bhṛtyānāṃ mantrī upalabdhiṃ vidhāya rājani nivedayati /
analyzed: yathā sarveṣām bhṛtyānām mantrī upalabdhim vidhāya rājani nivedayati
translated: Just as the minister, having ascertained the objects of all the servants, reports to the king,

analyzed: evam karmendriyāṇi prakāśya buddhau prayacchanti
translated: similarly, the organs of action reveal and hand over to the Buddhi.

analyzed: buddhiḥ api puruṣāya prayacchati samarpayati
translated: And the Buddhi also hands over, delivers to the Spirit.

original: anena prakāreṇa buddhir abhyudayaphalena /🔽yāvajjñānaṃ notpadyate tāvat puruṣaṃ yojayati /
analyzed: anena prakāreṇa buddhiḥ abhyudaya phalena  yāvat jñānam na utpadyate tāvat puruṣam yojayati
translated: In this way, the intellect connects the soul to the fruits of prosperity,

analyzed: svairiṇī iva kāmukam mūḍha vijñānam ghṛta ādi upacāraiḥ
translated: as long as knowledge does not arise, like a wanton woman connecting a lover with ghee and other services, due to deluded knowledge.

original: buddhipreritā ahaṃmanobuddhikarmendriyākhyā viṣayān na svārthaṃ na ca buddhyarthaṃ kiṃ tu puruṣārtham eva sādhayanti /🔽yathā salakṣmīkasvairiṇīgṛhe dāsyas tadādeśena rasavatīṃ na svārthaṃ na ca svāmitayāvasthitasvairiṇy arthaṃ kiṃ tu tayāpahṛtavivekavijñānasya
analyzed: buddhi preritāḥ aham manaḥ buddhi karma indriya ākhyāḥ viṣayān na sva artham na ca buddhi artham kim tu puruṣa artham eva sādhayanti  yathā salakṣmīka svairiṇī gṛhe dāsyaḥ tad ādeśena rasavatīm na sva artham na ca svāmi tayā avasthita svairiṇī artham kim tu tayā apahṛta viveka vijñānasya
translated: The intellect-directed senses called the organs of action and the mind, do not accomplish their own purpose or the purpose of the intellect, but only the purpose of the soul.

analyzed: kāmukasya kṛte nirvartayanti tadvat
